polish shares fell for the third session in a row hit by friday wall street plunge and analysts said falls on world 's stock exchanges and upcoming attractive primary offerings made a near-term rebound unlikely the main market 's wig index fell 417.2 points or 2.6 percent to 15,846.6 and turnover rose 7.5 percent to 160.9 million zlotys 53.7 million on all three markets as 80 issues fell six rose and six were flat they said warsaw was likely to fall or stay in horizontal trend with a slight falling tendency in the next few sessions unless the climate on world 's leading bourses improves `` the market looks bad we had falls in higher turnover despite strong friday 's buying ... and investors increasingly watch foreign bourses before making any decisions '' said tomasz berent an analyst at ib austria brokerage analysts said polish paper firm celuloza swiecie sa primary market offer of at least 112.5 million zlotys 37.3 million which starts on tuesday and metals trader impexmetal sa next week 's offering worth at least 222 million zlotys 74 million could significantly draw capital from the bourse some analysts said however a fall to 15,500 should spur some demand and help the bourse edge up they said tuesday 's inflation figure expected relatively low at below one percent was already priced-in but should contribute to the bourse 's better performance in longer-term they said polish central bank chief saying on friday that the government should achieve its 13 percent inflation goal for 1997 also bode well in the longer-term some said monthly earnings reports due later in the week could cause some sharp swings of selected stocks they expected construction stocks to show strong earnings growth over last year when they were hit by harsh winter

sydney futures exchange sfe wheat futures moved up sharply in heavier trading on monday as australian dry weather worsened and on world supply concerns near-term contracts traded on the sfe floor at a 6.00-a 9.00 a tonne higher a total of 35 contracts sold the biggest volume in many weeks nearby may 1997 rose a 7.00 to a 187.50 on the trade while january 1998 rose a 9.00 to a 183.00 settlement prices also rose strongly across the board with near-term contracts up by a 4.00-a 6.00 more distant contracts up by about a 8.00 and january 1988 up a 10.00 to a 184.00 the possibility of trade sanctions against iran dampening world wheat prices if australia was forced to unload millions of tonnes of discount wheat was not enough to hold the market back gary booth of ord minnett jardine fleming futures ltd said every day conditions south of sydney on australia 's eastern side were getting drier and drier demand for feed by the cattle industry was also growing `` the sydney market is finally reacting to domestic supply concerns what could be the emergence of drought conditions strong demand from the livestock industry australian wheat board awb sales and very low carryover stocks '' he said the threat of the u.s. big winter chill killing off large areas was another important market factor he said a downward market correction was likely in the next few days in reaction to monday 's gains and to the iran crisis he said `` i think that iran will probably weigh on the u.s. market tonight and we may see prices retrace a little '' he said but with soybeans at an eight and a half year high and ending stocks at 20 year lows in wheat and beans weather anomalies or continued drought could produce real trouble he said all this was producing an erratic wheat market which could be headed for a 200.00 where resistance was likely he said australia wheat futures on april 14 per tonne last net ch settle volume open interest may7 187.50 +7.00 185.50 9 115 july7 189.00 +6.00 cme live cattle futures rallied again late and closed at two-month highs buoyed by a firmer tone to cash cattle which touched off buy stops traders said feeder cattle futures ended higher but gains were pared after new contract highs were set traders said live cattle closed 0.775 cent per lb higher to 0.150 lower with august up most at 65.750 cents distant april set a new high feeder cattle ended 0.400 cent per lb higher to 0.075 lower with august up 0.025 at 81.150 cents after setting a new contract high of 82.000 cents early all but april and may feeders posted new contract highs on the early runup early resistance in live cattle lacked follow through and prices shot up late as short covering combined with commercial support to touch off chart-based buy stops floor sources said a stronger tone in both fed cattle and boxed beef sparked demand they said the futures rally began wednesday when packers raised bids to 62 as they became short of cattle for near-term needs and boxed beef sales were better than expected `` packers are still short cattle up north '' said jim clarkson analyst for a and a inc `` packers will likely pay more for cattle next week and feedlots will be asking 64 to 65 '' another trader added early analysts estimates on next friday 's total u.s. cattle inventory report as of july 1 were ranging from 108.4 million to 109.6 million head 97 to 98 percent of last year analyst projections on usda 's cattle-on-feed report ranged from 114 to 117 percent of a year ago for july 1 on-feed supplies in the seven key cattle feeding states with june placements ranging from 109 to 125.1 percent of a year ago and june marketings ranging from 101 to 106.9 percent rbh and lit division of first options continued to buy late while cargill investor services was buying october and selling august pit sources said feeders surged early to new contract highs on another gain in the cme feeder cattle index lower corn futures and outlooks for tight feeder supplies profit taking developed near midday when corn futures rallied but the runup in live cattle futures again prompted late short covering interest traders said the latest cme feeder cattle index jumped 0.62 per cwt to 81.37 a new high for the move and the highest level in over three years since april 15 1994 estimates on next week 's u.s. cattle inventory report point to feeder cattle supplies at 96.4 to 98 percent of last year as of july 1 early estimates on the projected 1997 calf crop were 97 to 98 percent boneless beef and beef trimmings futures also rallied late to new highs with trimmings pacing the advance on short covering and new buying following the runup in live cattle futures lind-waldock bought october and r.j. o'brien sold while rosenthal collins bought october traders said spreaders sold trimmings and bought boneless beef pit sources said trimmings ended 2.80 to 0.60 cent per lb higher with august up most at 48.00 cents august through december posted new contract highs boneless beef finished unchanged to 1.00 higher with august up 0.50 at 96.00 october and april set new contract highs jerry bieszk 312-408-8725

u.s. blue chips cut their losses in late afternoon trading wednesday prompting the new york stock exchange to lift curbs on program trading at 1442 edt/1842 gmt the dow industrials were off 21 points at 7739 the standard poor 's 500 index was off three points at 891 the nasdaq composite index also off its lows was down seven points to 1436 the index was suffering deeper losses about 0.5 percent than other broad-based stock indexes after two key technology companies forecast disappointing earnings gateway 2000 inc said late tuesday that second-quarter revenues would be flat compared to the first quarter seagate technology inc said its quarterly results would not meet wall street analysts estimates the long bond was up 14/32 to yield 6.69 percent

the average yield at this week 's tender for ten million dinars of 91-day bahrain treasury bills rose to 5.49 percent from 5.47 percent last week a spokesman for the bahrain monetary agency said on monday the average price dropped to 98.630 from 98.636 a week earlier and the minimum price accepted was 98.629 banks submitted bids for 24.7 million dinars worth of bills down from 34.1 million dinars the previous week the bills are offered on monday and issued on wednesday

the philippine peso closed slightly lower against the dollar on thursday and banks remained cautious after the two percentage-point cut in the central bank 's overnight rates banks believe speculation has not yet died down and a further lowering of the central bank 's overnight rate may rekindle this traders said the peso ended at 26.375 from 26.374 with volume higher at 202 million from 180.7 million `` the situation is still wobbly there is still negative sentiment in asia '' a foreign bank dealer said the peso was a victim of the recent asian currency turmoil which was caused by the problems of the thai baht this forced the central bank to raise its overnight borrowing last week in late deals the central bank had to unload 27 million at 26.375 traders said central bank governor gabriel singson earlier told reuters the central bank would bring down overnight rates to normal levels next week if market conditions stabilise -- lilian karunungan 63 2 841-8937

yen-based tokyo precious metals futures except for silver reversed early losses to end higher on friday as the dollar jumped against the yen in late tokyo trade japanese traders said palladium futures posted especially strong gains in afternoon trade with the four distant months rising their 48 yen per gram daily limits before retracing by the close benchmark june palladium ended up 43 yen at 721 yen per gram `` some private investors rushed to cover short positions on the yen 's sudden fall price movements were exaggerated by relatively thin market conditions '' one commodity broker said gold futures ranged from eight yen to 12 yen per gram higher benchmark june was up 12 yen at 1,217 yen spot gold was quoted weaker at 323.40/90 per ounce at 0757 gmt against 324.20/70 in new york on thursday `` speculative interest in gold futures remains thin with attention centring on pgms '' one trader said he said spot gold may probe downside support at 322.00 to 323.00 amid pressure from the dollar in the physical market japan 's gold demand has shown little sign of recovering while demand for pgms has been good they added -- tokyo commodities desk +81-3-3432-7431

shanghai rice futures closed down in active trade on thursday on technical selling after rice had been unable to break the 2,540/50-yuan level over the past few days traders said the key september 1996 contract ended at 2,508 yuan 302 per tonne losing 30 yuan it opened at 2,534 yuan hitting an intra-day high of 2,538 and a low of 2,471 october fell 25 to 2,525 yuan per tonne combined volume rose to 32,650 tonnes from 10,200 traders said technical sales triggered panic selling with the september contract falling below 2,500 yuan before institutional buying pulled prices off intra-day lows `` panic selling by individuals was responsible for today 's falls because they were disappointed with the movement of rice over the past few days '' one trader said but buying by institutions emerged below 2,500 yuan showing they will not let rice fall below that level easily traders said analysts said long position and short position holders of the september contract will fight at around 2,500 yuan in the next few days 1=8.3050 yuan

brazil 's government sold a total of 128,660 60-kg bags or 39.44 percent of the 326,188 bags offered in its monthly auction today said an official from banco do brasil which held the electronic sale total revenue from the auction was 16.05 million reais 17 million the official added details of closing prices per lot would be available later the official said -caroline bulloch rio de janeiro newsroom 5521 5074151

implied volatilities for u.s. fixed income options were little changed after slipping from early highs in choppy trading ahead of the march 25 federal open market committee meeting dealers said volatilities were bid when underlying markets tumbled early in the day on a slightly higher than expected february consumer price index but the bids soon dissipated as underlying prices held above key support levels `` basically it 's been pretty steady '' a brokerage trader at the chicago board of trade said of treasury bond volatilities `` everyone 's just waiting for fomc '' implied volatilities for cbot may and june t-bond options stood at around 9.6 and 9.5 percent respectively shortly before the close up marginaly from late tuesday levels but off some 0.2 point from early highs february cpi was up 0.3 percent overall in february against an average wall street estimate of a 0.2 percent rise and january 's 0.1 percent gain the core cpi excluding food and energy was up 0.2 percent in line with expectations among the few large option deals today an investment bank that was a big buyer of puts in recent weeks was seen buying 4,000 legs of may 106/108 put spreads april options which expire at the end of the week saw mixed flows in moderate sizes traders said federal reserve chairman alan greenspan 's testimony before a house banking and financial services subcommittee offered no market-moving remarks but they added that the market would keep an eye on greenspan when he speaks again on thursday before the joint economic committee at the shorter end of the yield curve eurodollar volatilities were steady to firmer on lingering fed tightening concerns implied volatility for september eurodollar futures options was up 0.1 point at around 12.8 percent while december was steady at around 14.1 percent `` the way the futures market rejected the attempt to rally back up after the number this morning was pretty negative '' said an investment bank at the chicago mercantile exchange `` we have n't exactly taken out key levels -- we sort of held the lows from the unemployment break 93.840 in september futures on march 7 '' he noted `` but i just think it 's a matter of time '' september futures dipped to a low of 93.850 early in the session the investment bank trader said even june futures which were seen to have priced-in a 25 basis point rate hike were still vulnerable because the fed could raise rates by 50 basis points perhaps in may if it did not tighten at the march fomc meeting among the larger deals an investment bank was seen selling june 94.25 calls and bought 94.00 puts in a 6,000-lot combo trade while a european firm sold december 94.00 calls and bought 94.25 calls in a 3,000-by-6,000 ratio spread chicago derivatives desk nwe straight-run fuel oil prices remained stable on thursday with buyers pushed onto the sidelines by uncertainty over the lasting strength of the rise in crude traders said very little business was seen done market players said a cargo of low sulphur straight-run sold on tuesday from ireland had gone for 106.50 slightly under notional offer prices of 107 and 108 some sellers said they were watching the rise in brent futures to see if it would hold but acknowledged that a healthy flow of supplies in europe and the med would undercut any price appreciation russian material has reappeared at baltic ports with buyers picking up cargoes on wednesday and more still on offer at three means 4 traders said london newsroom +44 171 542 8060

base metals by the end of friday 's london metal exchange lme trading fell back from their earlier highs though traders said this was mainly due to end-week profit-taking and light broker liquidation aluminium slipped from its earlier 3-1/2 month high of 1,535 a tonne while copper drifted towards 2,200 a tight physical market recent investment fund buying and uptrending charts helped to underpin the aluminium market `` although it 's below its highs aluminium has performed well on the upside a move that may encourge fresh short-covering next week '' one trader said three months delivery aluminium was last at 1,530 against thursday 's 1,504 close traders said aluminium 's performance reflected investment fund shorts following forward selling last october they said a large proportion of aluminium stocks are tied up in long term financing deals and are not readily available to the market to alleviate the growing tightness a break above resistance at 1,540 next week could spark a move towards 1,600 some traders said `` noone is likely to run the market short at the moment '' one commented he said there could be fresh consumer buying next week copper dipped from a high of 2,218 to settle at 2,208 down 4 overall the copper market remained quiet and continued to consolidate traders will watch closely the lme stocks data next week on tuesday and friday several are expecting inventories to rise after a long string of declines this would spark speculative selling though traders believed substantial tonnages would have to be delivered into lme warehouses before a full scale sell-off emerged they also said that the strong backwardation present in the market could attract material into lme warehouses the cash to three months backwardation was last at 135/ 145 versus levels of 40/50 that prevailed at the start of novemeber nickel on the back of buy-stops and despite an lme stocks rise snapped higher it was last at 6,910 a gain of 40 but given nickel 's recent poor chart performance which has seen prices down to a two-year low of 6,650 this week several traders expect further downside pressure next week other metals remained quiet zinc climbed by 4 to 1,080 lead was lsat at 710 down 3 tin settled at 6,115 against 6,160 alloy was at 1,370 against 1,345/50 -- london newsroom +44 71 510 8075

u.s. corporate bond spreads were firm in typically light monday trade except for sharp losses in debt from tci communications inc and mobilemedia corp dealers said junk-rated mobilemedia 's 9-3/8 percent debt traded off more than 10 basis points from friday 's close traders said following the company 's announcement that it may default on about 11 million in november debt service mobilemedia 's zero coupon debt also dropped 10 points to a 55 bid 60 offer market few bonds were said to trade despite the drop the company first said third quarter earnings could place it in violation of certain bank covenants in late september the company on monday said it is in talks with bank agents and is mulling whether it will make the coupon payments in other high-yield trade sinclair broadcast group debt was knocked one and a half points lower in response to news on friday that it expects flat revenues and a four to five percent decline in third quarter cash flow the 10 percent 2005 debt closed at 98-1/2 bid 99 offered sinclair shares dropped nine points to 34-3/4 meanwhile elsewhere high-grades traders pushed tci communications debt 15 basis points wider on average following a negative outlook by standard poor 's credit rating agency late on friday tci debt due in 2000 widened to a 122 basis point bid 111 offer compared with a 108 105 market on friday bid-ask spreads for tci debt widened more out the curve making for illiquid markets traders said tci 's 7-7/8s of 2026 were quoted at 275 bid 247 offer for example `` you had reluctant sellers who are n't showing tci 's very cheap and then distressed buyers who were saying 'hit me so there was n't a lot of commerce '' one high-grades trader said moody 's investors service inc cut tci 's senior unsecured debt to ba1 from baa3 on april 26 broadly speaking secondary high-grade trading was quiet in all sectors with spreads quoted mostly flat traders said in light new issuance bankamerica corp issued 250 million a2/single-a rated subordinated notes due 2011 as 7.125s to yield 7.218 percent or 72 basis points over the treasury curve also may department stores set 125 million 20-year a2/single-a rated debentures at par to yield 7.45 percent or 64 basis points over the treasury long bond high-yield issuance was dormant on monday but dealers and traders point to a rapidly mounting calendar supply comes in the face of suddenly negative mutual fund cash flows which have given the market a heavy tone traders said high-yield traders focused on approximately 10 to 12 new issues in the next week or copper prices perked up in late tuesday lme trading but conditions throughout the complex were fairly low-key and traders said that the red metal looked to be favouring a range-trading pattern latest lme stock data showed a 5,400-tonne increase which was the higher end of expectations but was not construed as a great surprise recent inventory movements have all been much as expected and with stocks now on an upward curve market volatility has subsided this week traders added `` it has been very slow today and there has been an element of `` winding down '' ahead of the year-end '' one analyst said copper prices were reasonably well defended on dips below 2,120 as was the case late last week and this area down to 2,100 is seen forming the lower level of a 50 technical range traders said next week 's `` third wednesday '' hurdle remains to be overcome but there is less concern over the december date now compared to two weeks ago as many positions have been squared off final three months business on the kerb was at 2,136 a tonne up 3 from monday 's kerb the cash/threes backwardation narrowed to around 138 from 162 yesterday elsewhere there was little excitement in the other metals although aluminium lost ground while tin and lead notched up fresh lows for the current downswing aluminium gradually fell away towards the 1,500 support level paying little attention to a lme warehouse stock fall or ipai producer inventory decline both of which had been expected last trade was at 1,503.50 down 5.50 tin suffered from investment fund liquidation against a backdrop of recent chinese and malaysian selling as well as rising lme inventories the market dropped to a fresh 1-1/2 year low of 5,760 before ending at 5,770 down 70 nickel was not helped by a 564-tonne stock increase although price declines were fairly light given the general slow conditions last trade was at 6,800 down 20 lead inched up after earlier equalling monday 's 13-month lows of 666 as this is important trend-line support but the overall outlook remains gloomy unless there is a severe cold snap in the northern hemisphere prices closed at 672 a 5.50 gain the zinc market was sluggish throughout but was aided by a 2,425-tonne fall in stocks three months closed at 1,045 up 3 from the previous close aluminium alloy held around overnight levels closing at a steady 1,352/54 a tonne -- martin hayes london shanghai 's b share index closed up on monday with domestic investors actively building positions on confidence in the short-term stability of the market and due to recent rises in chinese stocks in hong kong brokers said the index ended up 0.972 points or 1.45 percent at 68.129 points on volume of 19.3 million shares worth 8.5 million brokers said market sentiment was strong because there were no signs of political instability after the death of chinese leader earlier this month the gains in the h shares of chinese firms listed in hong kong added confidence to the b share market they said `` domestic investors believe that the recent strong performance of h shares in hong kong indicates overseas investors have confidence in china 's future '' said one broker `` they believe that after the gains in the h shares overseas capital will flow into the b share market as well '' he added `` technical charts have indicated that the b market is ready for a breakthrough '' said a second broker `` the near-term trend will depend on whether the b share index can breach the key 69-point resistance level on tuesday '' on monday 's trading all 43 b shares in shangahi traded with 34 up four flat and five down stationery maker shanghai hero was the star performer after it posted strong 1996 results last saturday brokers said the stock rose 0.028 or 6.73 percent to 0.444 on volume of 675,200 shares toy maker shanghai haixin traded the most and became the second winner on talk of good results for 1996 brokers said it added 0.030 or 6.12 percent to 0.520 on volume of 1.3 million shares shanghai 's a share index closed higher with fresh liquidity flowing into the market on strong sentiment brokers said it rose 24.033 points or 2.21 percent to 1,111.456 points on volume of 848.4 million shares worth 8.4 billion yuan the sse 30 blue-chip index rose 53.090 points or 1.88 percent to 2,872.488 points shanghai tyre and rubber was the biggest gainer on the news that one of its projects had been chosen as a key project for the city in 1997 brokers said the stock surged 1.06 yuan to end at a 10-percent limit-up of 11.62 yuan on volume of 1.0 million shares -- shanghai argentina 's economy ministry said it will make a 750 million dollar-denominated bond issue in international markets the bonds will have a 10-year maturity the ministry said lead underwriters of the issue to be registered with the u.s. securities and exchange commission sec will be goldman sachs and co and salomon brothers inc `` this issue falls within the budget authorization approved by congress for the current period and allows us to benefit from the favorable conditions in international financial markets as well as to extend the term of debt placements '' a ministry statement said the ministry provided no further details on the timing of the issue -- gary regenstreif buenos aires newsroom 541 318-0618

zimbabwean president robert mugabe returned home on monday from a four-day state visit to jamaica which he said was aimed at boosting political and trade ties mugabe was accompanied by his wife grace four government ministers and several state officials to the carribbean island where he visited the capital kingston and two resort towns of negril and montego bay zimbabwe and jamaica established diplomatic ties in 1980 and trade between the two countries was valued at just over z 400,000 in 1995 when the southern african state imported alcohol worth z 334,000 and jamaica bought furniture worth z 80,000 -- -cris chinaka harare newsroom +263-4 72 52 27/8/9

washington gov gary locke on tuesday unveiled a plan to replace the state 's welfare system with a program that would require recipients to work and provide aid to legal immigrants under locke 's plan 60,200 people -- more than two-thirds of all those applying for assistance -- would be required to actively look for work or participate in job training locke said in a statement that his program would provide both `` the positive incentives and the firm hand needed to move people off welfare and into jobs '' locke 's so-called `` workfirst '' program would provide child care health care and job training to help people find jobs the program also adopts the five-year lifetime limit on benefits prescribed under the new federal welfare law those who do not cooperate with the work requirements would be penalized with grant reductions locke said locke said his program would provide aid to legal immigrants who are denied eligibility for federal supplemental security income ssi and food stamps under the new federal welfare reform law locke said his budget proposal which he plans to release next week would include funding to serve people denied eligibility for the federal ssi benefits under the state 's general assistance-unemployment program food stamps would also be available to legal immigrants who meet the same criteria as other residents of the state the governor said `` the approach i am proposing is both fair and financially sound '' locke said in the statement `` it treats people equally and offers us the best chance in decades to attack poverty protect our most vulnerable neighbors and move the poor into the economic maintream '' locke said his budget would include nearly 100 million in additional funding for child care and 7.9 million to offer work-based learning programs to low-income students other components of the workfirst program include a requirement that able-bodied people who are unable to find employment perform community service and a wage subsidy to employers who hire people on assistance locke 's welfare reform proposal would also require that teen parents participate in education programs and live with their parents or in `` an approved living situation '' to qualify for assistance the governor said

u.s. president bill clinton and chinese president jiang zemin agreed on sunday on a framework for summit talks over the next two years that will start with a visit to china by vice president al gore in the first part of 1997 `` the two presidents have accepted each other 's invitations for state visits '' in 1997 and 1998 white house spokesman mike mccurry said after clinton and jiang met for 85 minutes on the fringes of the annual asia-pacific economic cooperation apec forum mccurry said it remained to be decided whether washington or beijing would be the site of the first summit and exactly when the summits would take place but he said gore would start an exchange of high-level visits by u.s. and chinese officials by going to china in the first half of 1997 the last u.s. president to visit china was george bush in 1989 ties between the united states and china started unravelling in june of that year because of the tiananmen square clampdown on chinese dissidents and have been more or less frosty ever since clinton and jiang `` agree that this very important relationship needs regular high-level visits '' mccurry said a senior u.s. official who briefed reporters after the two presidents met indicated they agreed on very little else at their meeting which the official described as `` straightforward '' and `` businesslike '' chinese foreign ministry spokesman shen guofang described the talks as constructive and said the presidents agreed their meeting was important for the future of u.s.-china relations the u.s. official said clinton and jiang covered a broad range of issues including nuclear non-proliferation taiwan china 's desire for membership of the world trade organisation wto north korea and human rights clinton rejected jiang 's demand for an end to u.s. sponsorship of a u.n. resolution that criticises china 's record on human rights and also told him that china needs to do more to become a member of the wto trade body the official said he said jiang complained about u.s. arms sales to taiwan but that this was not a major topic of discussion `` it got very little treatment in this meeting but i do n't mean to pretend or assert that this does n't remain a very significant issue for the chinese '' the official said despite their differences the clinton-jiang meeting was apparently cordial even light-hearted at times when clinton noted that he was hoarse because of his recent re-election campaign and his travels jiang jokingly suggested he try chinese medicine or acupuncture the chinese leader also told clinton that the wreck of a u.s. b-24 bomber had recently been found in southern china with some human remains aboard apparently those of u.s. servicemen missing since world war two jiang gave the u.s. president a videotape and photographs of the crash site and invited him to send a u.s forensic team to china to inspect it clinton speaking with reporters at the start of a subsequent meeting with japanese prime minister ryutaro hashimoto said he was pleased with the meeting `` i think it went very well it was a good meeting and i think the next steps are appropriate '' clinton said

colombia 's state employees launched a nationwide strike on tuesday and immediately drew support from the country 's leftist rebels who vowed to back workers demands for higher pay with armed force union bosses said the indefinite work stoppage -- billed as the biggest in 20 years -- had won the `` total '' support of an estimated 800,000 public sector employees and severely disrupted the nation 's airports telecommunications oil production government administration and all but emergency health services government officials and spokesmen for the state oil company ecopetrol played down the economic impact of the strike but admitted concern over threatened rebel attacks coinciding with the labour action `` the strike is total workers have observed the call en masse and some social sectors are also joining in '' said hernando hernandez head of the oil workers union uso known for its combative fiercely nationalistic stance `` so far everything is passing off in a peaceful fashion there are no reports of violence '' he added though hernandez said ecopetrol had been severely affected by the strike a senior company official told reuters there was no effect whatsoever administrative employees were filling in for union workers as part of a strike contingency plan and production and pumping operations were proceeding normally the official said state workers called the strike to press for a 21.5 percent wage hike the government which is struggling to slash its burgeoning fiscal deficit vowed to hold workers to a weighted 13.5 percent increase the strike began at midnight monday 0500 gmt on tuesday and is to last indefinitely a communique issued by national liberation army eln rebels just hours after the strike began underscored what authorities had already described as the threat of imminent rebel attacks `` we support our union comrades but simply making demands through a strike is not sufficient '' the communique said `` these actions must go hand in hand with effective pressure tactics and expressions of violence and grassroots disobedience as the only method to resolve the real problems of the nation '' it said its backing of the strike was a preamble to what it termed a `` national armed strike '' in the past the eln has used so-called `` armed strikes '' to shut down vast regions of the country blockading major highways setting fire to vehicles and threatening people who show up for work the eln founded by radical roman catholic priests in the mid-1960s specialises in economic sabotage and attacks on multinational companies even before the eln communique was made public tight security was clamped on the capital of bogota where a ban on alcohol was declared late on monday by mayor antanas mockus and a lack of public transportation prevented thousands of people from getting to work on tuesday morning state-run schools and universities across the country were shut down by the government as a security measure heavy detachments of riot police and army troops stood guard outside public offices in the downtown area and police helicopters hovered over plaza de bolivar the city 's main square where an estimated 20,000 strikers gathered to protest outside congress on tuesday afternoon francisco hernandez a spokesman for bogota 's el dorado international airport said operations were `` more or less normal '' early on tuesday some carriers including continental and american airlines suspended all operations in and out of colombia since airport firemen had threatened to disrupt operations a spokesman for the national exporters association said vast shipments of cut flowers to the united states in preparation for this week 's st. valentine 's day holiday had not been affected because they were flown out of colombia on domestic carriers

hungary urged by the international monetary fund imf to cut its inflation more quickly may revise its 1998 economic policy plans finance minister peter medgyessy told the daily magyar hirlap on monday medgyessy who attends the world economic forum in davos told magyar hirlap that he had talks with imf deputy chief executive officer stanley fisher there stanley recognized the results of hungary 's two-year-old economic stabilisation programme by which the country substantially reduced its budget and current account deficits but added that hungary should reduce inflation more quickly medgyessy said `` following this i had the idea that perhaps we should work with alternative inflation plans when we prepare the 1998 budget draft '' medgyessy said `` one would calculate with the originally planned five percent cut for 1998 while the other with an even larger reduction '' he added hungary cut inflation to 23.6 percent in 1996 from 29.2 percent in 1995 and targets 16 to 18 percent for 1997 -- budapest newsroom 36 1 327 4040

downward pressure on the czech crown has subsided following a series of czech national bank cnb moves but analysts warned on tuesday that another attack on the currency is likely as the cnb measures are eased after months of rock-solid stability the crown came under fire last week from short-selling especially by foreign investors that pushed it to record lows of more than five percent below its basket parity prompting the cnb to intervene for the first time in more than a year the cnb said the crown 's fall was due to fluctuations of several foreign currencies and not for fundamental reasons adding that the bearish pressure has subsided this week but analysts said they expect another attack on the crown to begin once the central bank begins to loosen its grip regardless of the reason behind the first attempt `` what tends to happen in situations like this is that you get a second attack ... and i think you have to expect that '' said pavel pinkava a london-based currency dealer at nomura international pavel sobisek of zivnostenska banka in prague agreed `` the cnb showed a strong commitment to keep the crown at current levels but similar attacks on the crown look quite probable for the future '' the crown was steady at around 2.0 percent below parity of the central bank 's mark/dollar basket in tuesday afternoon trading from -3.8 percent on friday in an attempt to ward off bearish investors the central bank last friday raised its lombard rate to 50 percent from a previous 14 percent and followed up with a rise in repo rates to 45 percent from 12.9 percent analysts said the moves may have cost the central bank as much as 1 billion but they appeared to have had their desired effect banks have raised rates and the crown has moved closer to parity if the central bank continued to stand its ground it should win the war and beat back the tide of weaker crown sentiment analysts said `` the cnb has got to stand tough right now it is under government pressure over the economy but if it holds on it can withstand another wave and win this battle '' said one local dealer `` over the next couple of weeks the market will be pretty quiet and then there will be a final attack which i think will resolve itself in favour of the central bank and then they investors will walk away '' he added nomura 's pinkava agreed he said the central bank would have to hold rates at current levels for two to three weeks but that in the end the central bank should come out on top `` at the end of the day these crises often resolve themselves in favour of the central bank especially the first few times investors attack and especially in this market which is n't that deep '' he said -- prague newsroom 420-2-2423-0003

one third of shanghai 's state companies are in the red despite a rapid increase in the city 's industrial output this year the wen hui bao newspaper reported on sunday in the first seven months of 1996 shanghai 's industrial output value grew 15.5 percent over the same 1995 period and value of industrial product sales grew 15.4 percent it said but gave no further figures industrial enterprises in shanghai are significantly more efficient than average companies in china but one third of the state firms are running at a loss the newspaper said it did not give reasons for the losses to turn these deficits into profits state firms must develop markets and their own products it said they must deepen reform and improve the level of management and the quality of their managers it said but gave no further details there are about 4,000 state firms in shanghai like state firms elsewhere in china shanghai firms suffer from excess manpower outdated equipment a heavy burden of debts and retired workers and low efficiency

the head of investment analysis at credit suisse private banking said he thought swiss interest rates would move sideways for the rest of the year before rising slightly in 1998 swiss interest rates seem near a low point in this business cycle alexander galli told the finanz und wirtschaft newspaper in an interview published on saturday `` but the leeway for rates on the long end to go down does not seem completely exausted because the swiss economy will hardly leave the stagnation phase in 1997 and inflation is less than one percent '' he said real long-term rates of 2 to 2.5 percent are still relatively high while one percent seems close to the lower limit in the money market he said `` i thus expect a sideways movement of money and capital market rates in switzerland that could lead to a slight increase next year this is also true if the economy starts growing again in 1998 and inflation fears perhaps arise '' he said `` but i do n't see a significant change in interest rates because marked increases are not expected in either the united states or germany '' he added galli said the discount rate was already at an extraordinarily low level of 1.0 percent but it was possible the swiss national bank would cut it again `` a further reduction -- for example to 0.5 percent -- would not change anything about monetary policy given the massive expansion of money on offer already but would show the national bank 's will to do its utmost to support the ... swiss economy `` if it does this it has at most symbolic value because demand for discount credits has never had much significance for monetary policy '' he said -- zurich newsroom +41 1 631 7340

the state central bank of pakistan said it had auctioned short-term federal bonds worth 50 million rupees in an open market operation on thursday it said bids worth 50 million rupees were accepted for the outright sale of the six-month bonds at a maximum cut off of 16.75 percent a year in the previous auction held on january 29 the central bank accepted bids worth 400 million rupees for five-month repurchase contract of the bonds at a maximum cut-off of 16.50 percent -- karachi newsroom 9221-5685192

the world trade organisation wto established a dispute settlement panel to rule on a u.s. complaint against turkey 's 25 percent tax on box office receipts generated by the showing of foreign films a wto spokesman said the united states told the wto dispute settlement body that turkey 's municipality tax discriminated against foreign-origin films as no such tax was imposed on box office receipts from the showing of domestic films according to trade sources both the u.s. and turkish trade delegations said they hoped that a solution could be found to the dispute which began last year canada reserved its rights as a third-party to the dispute according to trade sources

a trend towards increasing economic and political decentralisation could drive india 's second stage of radical reform britain 's economist magazine said on friday a special report on india will appear in the february 22 issue of the magazine an advance copy of which was given to reuters it said prime minister h.d deve gowda 's ruling coalition is too fragile to successfully meet the challenges that must be surmounted to avoid falling behind other developing nations it called for the pace of economic reforms which began pulling down the decades-old walls of a socialist economy in 1991 to be accelerated `` though india is changing faster than at any time since british rule came to an end the government must accelerate the pace of reform to avoid falling further behind other developing nations especially the east asian tigers '' it said reforms have pushed the country 's growth rate from four percent a year between 1960 and 1990 to roughly seven percent a year since 1994 the magazine said in a statement that accompanied the report `` india 's reformers still have a great deal to do before the task begun in 1991 is complete '' it warned the survey found many public sector enterprises as well as private sector businesses still remain protected against competition though india 's markets have opened to competition though india has reduced its weighted average import tariff to 27 percent from the 1991 level of 87 percent the figure is still twice as high as the average in most of east asia and latin america the economist said in foreign direct investment fdi it said india appears at first glance to be making great progress india received nearly 2 billion of fdi in 1995 -- a handsome increase over 1991 's 150 million but only a fraction of the 38 billion fdi china received in 1995 `` the reason for this as foreign investors unanimously complain is that the system simply does not work as it is supposed to '' the economist said `` india 's future depends on radical reform strong political leadership and a willingness by government to confine its role in the economy to those few crucial areas where free enterprise alone is not enough '' the magazine said `` however the ruling coalition -- an ill-matched grouping of 13 different parties is too fragile to meet these challenges '' but the survey discerned signs that decentralisation could ultimately drive india 's second stage of radical reform `` if states gain more control of their own economic destinies reform-minded state governments could become pioneers of liberalisation promoting competition between states that would in turn promote further reform '' the economist concluded -- bombay newsroom +91-22-265 9000

the focus on tax legislation shifts to the senate next week where a key republican plans to unveil his version of how to cut taxes by a net 85 billion over 5 years the house ways and means committee friday approved a tax cut bill that will ultimately have to be reconciled with the senate version senate finance committee chairman william roth a delaware republican was scheduled to unveil his plan tuesday of how to implement the tax portion of the balanced budget agreement reached between congressional leaders and the white house white house unhappiness with the bill passed by the house committee will also have to be dealt with at some point house speaker newt gingrich said republicans will have to negotiate with president clinton to get a tax bill he will sign but that did not mean they would accept a major rewrite `` we will sit down with the president 's folks and with the president and try to reach an accomodation on issues of great importance to the president '' gingrich said but the georgia republican said that as long as the bill conformed to the overall budget agreement made with clinton `` i do n't think we have an obligation '' to let the white house rewrite it the white house has already begun mounting a campaign for changes in the congressional tax legislation white house spokesman mike mccurry said clinton found several aspects of the legislation `` quite objectionable '' `` the ways and means bill included despite the protests of the president ... some of those very features he considers quite objectionable this is not the bill that 's going to be signed into law '' mccurry said an outline of proposals that roth is considering putting into his legislation showed similarity with the house bill on education tax initiatives that the white house is raising objections about the outline showed the senate finance committee proposal for clinton 's hope scholarship tax credit would like the house bill be a 50 percent tax credit for up to 3,000 of college tuition expenses clinton 's proposal would have made it a straight 1,500 tuition tax credit for higher education administration officials have said the congressional legislation would penalize students attending less-expensive schools like community colleges who might not get the full 1,500 the education tax initiatives in the broad senate finance committee outline were given a preliminary cost estimate of 30 billion over five years the white house has already raised a ruckus over the fact that in the house legislation education tax initiatives were below the 35 billion over five years that clinton sought the balanced budget agreement had said `` roughly '' 35 billion should be included for education tax initiatives the senate finance committee outline also included a capital gains tax cut to 20 percent from the current maximum of 28 percent for individuals the same as in house legislation it did not have anything for a corporate capital gains tax cut the house bill would gradually cut the corporate capital gains tax rate to 30 percent from the current 35 percent the senate finance outline included expanding individual retirement accounts ira which has been a priority for roth it had a proposed 500 per child tax credit that would cost an estimated 83 billion over five years that would be a higher cost than the 71 billion in the house ways and means committee bill the child credit would be allowed for children under age 17 and parents with children aged 13-16 would be required to deposit the credit into an education ira a proposal in both bills for estate tax relief would phase in a higher threshold where the inheritance tax kicks in to 1 million from the current 600,000 gingrich said he expected the measure from the house ways and means committee would pass the house

finance minister theo waigel following the weekend meeting of european finance ministers in dublin said he sees no insurmountable problems clarifying details of the proposed erm ii or the stability pact he added that britain 's participation in european economic and monetary union emu would be desirable `` i see no more insurmountable problems '' waigel said in response to a question at a political party meeting details of the stability pact that remain to be worked out include how sanctions will be imposed for those countries that do not continue to fulfil the convergence criteria after the start of emu he said participants must also narrow the definitions of terms such as `` exceptional '' and `` temporary '' defining the precise circumstances that would allow a country to acceptably exceed the criteria he said waigel initially proposed the concept of a stability pact as a means of ensuring that countries which pass the economic test set for entry to the single currency do not later become lax in their fiscal policies over the weekend officials said a german proposal calling for a deposit of 0.25 percent of gdp for each percentage point of excess deficit was still on the table alongside a european commission proposal for a smaller deposit per percentage point capped at a maximum of 0.5 percent on britain 's participation in emu waigel said `` i hope that the currency union includes as many stability countries as possible and the united kingdom is one of these stability countries '' the financial world is greatly interested that britain not exclude itself from european integration and emu he said -- bonn newsroom 49 228 26097150

pilots at american airlines said wednesday they have reached a tentative labor agreement with american the nation 's second-largest carrier a spokesman for the 9,300-member allied pilots association said the accord was tentative and required approval by the union 's board and by member pilots american is a unit of amr corp.. terms of the agreement were not immediately disclosed the accord was reached after a day of talks in washington and weekend negotiations near seattle that were overseen by robert harris chairman of the emergency board created by president clinton last month to try to resolve the dispute the pilot 's union spokesman said the tentative agreement would be submitted to the allied pilots association 's apa board which is to meet in washington on friday he added that if the board approved it the pact would then be voted on by union members the main issues in the dispute which caused a brief strike last month before clinton stepped in had been wages and whether apa pilots would fly new commuter jets american is buying for its regional carrier american eagle

colombia 's central bank announced friday it had authorized the issuance of 1.8 billion in bonds to be sold in foreign markets in 1997 in a statement the bank said the bonds would be for terms of more than five years in 1995 the central bank issued 1.4 billion bonds in foreign capital markets the central bank said the interest rates would be fixed or variable depending on prevailing market conditions when the debt is sold no dates have been set for the bonds `` the no.1 priority for placing bonds in 1997 will be to obtain financial resources on ever better terms using a mixture of maturities and costs '' finance minister jose antonio ocampo said in an interview with reuters earlier this week the central bank said it would issue 5.28 trillion pesos in treasury bonds to local markets in 1997 to fund part of the national budget -- karl penhaul bogota newsroom 571 610 7944

south africa should have recorded a healthy trade surplus in december paving the way to an improving trade balance in 1997 lead by higher exports economists said on friday the consensus forecast of analysts polled by reuters was for a 760 million rand trade surplus in december up from 378 million in november although commentators cautioned the monthly figure was notoriously volatile the south african revenue services sars gives only cumulative export and import figures for the year to date from which economists compute the monthly trade balance all analysts forecast a surplus for december with ideas ranging between 400 million rand and 1.3 billion boe natwest economist nick barnardt at the top of the range said he was upbeat on the december data `` i 'm expecting a surplus of about 1.3 billion -- december is seasonallly a low import month '' he said a sars official said no firm date had yet been fixed for the release of december trade data but it could be published as early as monday south africa 's trade position has been improving in recent months as the sharp fall in the rand -- which tumbled 29 percent against the dollar in 1996 -- helps exports while a slowdown in the non-agricultural economy curbs imports however economists said the full effects of the currency depreciation would only be felt in the trade balance in 1997 `` the positive impact of the depreciation on the export sector will only come through fully in 1997 at the same time imports will be increasingly constrained following a fair amount of pre-emptive buying in 1996 '' said hania farhan economist at ing barings farhan expects south africa to record a trade surplus of 3.1 billion in 1997 up from 2.2 billion in 1996 which should help curb the country 's current account deficit significantly in 1997 constantin vayenas emerging markets analyst at ubs in london said on thursday he expected the current account deficit to narrow to 1.6 billion in 1997 from 2.5 billion in 1996 the central statistical service said the december consumer price index which many economists had expected to be released next week would not be available until the last week of january due to delays in receiving all surveys december preliminary money supply data is also due in the week commencing january 27 -- johannesburg newsroom 27 11 482 1003

inter-american development bank iadb head enrique iglesias friday declared support for government plans to impose austerity measures to cut the country 's bduget deficit `` ecuador has some problems with the budget deficit which the government has to face up to i think that it is taking the necessary measures and in the next few weeks there will be announcements '' iglesias told reporters in quito where he is assessing the country 's economy iglesias said that government officials had informed him of some measures to cut the deficit which are due to be announced monday but declined to say what they were `` i think that ecuador has a chance of significant improvement in the future '' he said he said that the iadb does not make policy recommendations to governments the 1.3 billion deficit is equivalent to 6.6 percent of ecuador 's gross domestic product the government has refused to reveal details of monday 's austerity announcements but official sources told reuters that increases in the prices of fuels and domestic gas are being studied -- gustavo oviedo quito newsroom +5932 25-8433

dain bosworth inc said it won 9.280 million of minneapolis-st. paul metropolitan council minn. general obligation refunding bonds series 1997d with a true interest cost of 4.528 percent

the city of moscow is planning to issue a eurobond with a three-year maturity rather than a longer one because the bond is a debut issue not because of any restrictions from the central bank a spokesman for the city government said on wednesday `` last summer when we started thinking about our eurobond we decided it should be short as it is our first '' mikhail chernyshov told reuters moscow will issue a 400 million three-year eurobond this summer some western bankers said the central bank had restricted regional eurobond maturities to three years by issuing a foreign exchange licence for only three years a central bank official said the bank the finance ministry and the federal commission on the securities markets were working on a package of regulation for regional eurobond issues he said the three-year term of the licence may be changed but gave no more details russia does not yet have a proper legislation on regional eurobond issues president boris yeltsin had to approve issues by the city of moscow st petersburg and nizhny novgorod -- julie tolkacheva moscow newsroom +7095 941 8520

french president jacques chirac warning of a humanitarian disaster appealed to the international community on thursday to make good on an agreement to allow iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to buy food chirac told a joint news conference in amman with jordan 's king hussein that the situation in iraq which faces widespread malnutrition and infant mortality due to a six-year u.n. trade embargo was `` unworthy of the modern age '' `` the population is suffering more and more and the health situation is disturbing '' chirac said `` this is unacceptable from a humanitarian point of view and extremely dangerous from a political point of view to the stability of the region '' earlier on thursday chirac used a speech to jordan 's parliament to highlight his differences with the united states over iraq which has been under stringent trade sanctions since its 1990 invasion of kuwait `` france is alarmed at the humanitarian situation in iraq and calls solemnly on the international community to apply at long last resolution 986 which provides for the resumption of oil exports against the purchase of food and medicine to save innocent lives from tragedy '' he said in a clear reference to washington which is holding up a deal agreed last may to implement the resolution chirac said `` the iraqi people can not be held responsible for decisions to which it was not party nor can it be held hostage for stakes that are alien to it `` the way ahead is clear and involves the implementation of all security council resolutions -- but only those resolutions '' he said to thunderous applause french officials privately accuse the united states of thwarting any easing of the stranglehold on iraq by adding demands on president saddam hussein that go beyond u.n. resolutions calling for iraq 's partial disarmament recognition of kuwait and compensation for gulf war damage chirac said later at the news conference that `` obstacles from both sides '' were blocking implementation of the deal king hussein who has called for the overthrow of saddam and provided a haven for the iraqi opposition said he shared chirac 's concern and hoped there would be an opportunity for `` inter-iraqi dialogue to resolve all problems '' `` a healthy iraq in this region is a necessity '' he said in september washington blocked implementation of the oil-for-food deal following a renewed confrontation with baghdad over iraq 's intervention in fighting between rival kurdish factions in northern iraq in new york u.n. diplomats said it could take months to put resolution 986 into practice because the united states is blocking an oil pricing formula u.n. officials say iraq faces a humanitarian emergency throughout the country because of a scarcity of food and medicine and inadequate water treatment because of sanctions

by paul stewart chief economist at anz banking group nz ltd wellington sept 13 i am sure central bankers would like to think that the process of controlling inflation involves much more science than art but the reality is that policy makers rely upon personal judgement gut feel and a bit of luck more than they would ideally like nonetheless considerable effort does go into developing an objective framework which determines what monetary policy settings are appropriate at any point in time a recent issue of the economist contained an article about one such attempt the rule developed in 1993 by john taylor an economist at stanford university taylor currently an adviser to bob dole argued that central banks should `` lean against the wind '' when setting interest rates and provide a method to calculate the appropriate level of short term interest rates given the prevailing inflation and growth conditions the economist noted that both taylor 's work and subsequent research suggested that the central banks in the u.s. germany and japan have whether by accident or design effectively been following the rule for some time so what about new zealand taylor 's rule says that short term interest rates say 90 day bank bills should be equal to the real short term interest rate i.e actual interest rate less inflation which is consistent with `` neutral '' monetary policy plus the expected inflation rate plus minus 0.5 percent for every percent that current inflation is above below its target plus minus 0.5 percent for every percent that current gdp growth is above below the potential gdp growth rate as a starting point for new zealand we adopted five percent as the neutral real short term interest rate three percent as the potential growth rate and the rbnz 's underlying inflation forecast 12 months forward as the expected inflation rate on that basis what does taylor 's rule tell us about monetary policy in the 1990s firstly it suggests that in the late 1993/early 1994 monetary policy was too loose in retrospect most would agree that to be a fair assessment because with the economy strengthening the rbnz 's inflation forecasts at that point were overly optimistic secondly it suggests that monetary policy is currently overly restrictive according to the rule short term interest rates should be around 2.5-3.0 percent lower than they are at present however thirdly it suggests that apart from the brief period in 1993-94 monetary policy has been too tight for all of the last six years and that is where the rule or our application of it starts to go wrong if monetary policy has been consistently too tight then clearly underlying inflation should have been less than one percent the mid-point of the target possibly even below zero percent for most of that period the fact that underlying inflation has never been below one percent and has spent a considerable amount of time near the top of or above the inflation target implies that monetary policy has if anything been too loose so what is wrong with the rule and why does n't it apply to new zealand an important issue is that taylor 's rule focuses exclusively upon interest rates that may be reasonably appropriate for the u.s. but in a small trade-dependent economy where the exposure to imported inflation is much higher a measure which does not explicitly capture the impact of the exchange rate on monetary conditions will be incomplete another possibility is that we have applied the rule incorrectly specifically we have rather subjectively set the `` neutral '' real short term interest rate at five percent we could use the average historical short term rate for the u.s. and u.k. that is around two percent and 3.5 percent respectively indeed applying new zealand 's average for the last six years around 6.5 percent does improve the fit of the rule to actual rates however in another research paper cited by the economist alison stuart of the bank of england notes that `` theoretically '' the neutral real short term rate should be close to the long run trend rate of economic growth that would imply a much lower rate for new zealand 3.0-3.5 percent which would then reduce the performance of the taylor rule further taylor 's rule seems to add little in the new zealand context and i would argue has limited use for any economy the fact is that the process of controlling inflation and setting monetary policy is not a simple mechanical process based on exact information economic relationships are complex and contingent upon the human factor changeable through time the difficulty faced by central bankers in rigorously analysing large amounts of sketchy and often lagged information as a basis for setting policy which will have an imprecise impact upwards of a year into the future should not be underestimated however this exercise has reinforced one important point that is real short term interest rates in new zealand have remained persistently high compared to other industrialised economies why is that essentially despite modest inflation expectations generally measured at 2.0-3.0 percent household and business behaviour is not yet consistent with a low inflation environment new zealanders appear to have a very high propensity to borrow especially for property investment and are reluctant to save even with high real interest rates until that changes the reserve bank will have to `` lean a little more heavily against the wind '' than the taylor rule advocates note the opinions expressed in this article represent the views of the author only they should not be seen as reflecting the views of reuters

french unemployment leapt to a record in august with the biggest monthly increase in more than three years pushing the jobless rate to 12.6 percent at a time when government economic policy is under increasing fire the number of people out of work in france jumped 39,500 in august to 3,085,100 and the jobless rate based on international labour organisation ilo criteria which exclude jobseekers who did any work hit a record 12.6 percent up from 12.5 percent `` it 's an extraordinary number quite a shock '' said philippe brossard an economist with abn amro investment bank in paris the leap in jobless numbers will turn up the heat on prime minister alain juppe whose policy of austerity and spending cuts is coming under increasing criticism from the ranks of his own centre-right ruling coalition as well as trade unions `` this is going to raise the gloom and unhappiness in the parliament we 're heading for a tough political weekend '' said brossard juppe has called a parliamentary confidence vote for next wednesday in an effort to unite his fractious coalition sniping from within his own rpr party prompted president jacques chirac to intervene in juppe 's defence on thursday juppe has been counting on an upturn in the economy in the second half of this year and had got a fillip from news earlier this week that household spending was gathering pace but the latest jobless figures will do nothing to help his efforts to talk up public morale as juppe and chirac fight to dispel gloom and crank up consumer spending and business investment brossard and several other specialists said the latest news reinforced the view that there would have to be further interest rate cutting by the bank of france to help the economy economists said it was still hard to measure the social and political fall-out `` clearly it 's important because it comes amid tensions in the government but as long as chirac supports juppe we should not have too much of a political fight '' said david naude an economist with jp morgan bank despite already simmering labour union tension naude said the surge in unemployment could actually have the effect of cowing people rather than sparking unrest `` when people see jobless numbers rising they may be less willing to demand pay rises or strike '' he said `` it 's not clear-cut '' valerie plagnol an economist at credit commercial de france said `` it does increase the potential for social tensions when there is little hope for unemployment and these are only august numbers there were plans to cut more jobs in a number of sectors in september '' `` it also means that pickup in household consumption in third quarter wo n't be supportive for the fourth quarter economic growth the momentum beyond third quarter can not be assured at all '' she said french unemployment had fallen by 20,000 in july but that drop had been written off by economists as an aberration due to seasonal factors `` the figures are the reflection of an economy that remains weak i would expect unemployment to keep edging up to reach around 12.7 12.8 percent by the end of the year '' jean-louis mourier economist at louis dreyfus finance said in the wake of the august data

by the biggest majority yet the u.n. general assembly adopted a resolution on tuesday for the fifth year in a row calling for an end to the three-decade-old u.s. trade embargo against cuba the vote was 137 to three with 25 abstentions voting against were the united states israel and uzbekistan a similar resolution last year received 117 votes with the same three countries opposed and 38 abstentions as in the past u.s. allies as well as adversaries backed the cuban draft because they regard the embargo as violating their own sovereignty by subjecting them to the effects of washington 's laws and regulations the 15-nation european union three of whose members -- britain germany and the netherlands -- abstained last year this time voted solidly in favour of the resolution other countries that switched to a yes vote from an abstention last year included the czech republic hungary poland romania slovakia and turkey russia china canada mexico argentina and brazil were among those voting for the cuban resolution as in the past abstainers included japan saudi arabia south korea jordan kuwait morocco estonia latvia and lithuania criticism of u.s. policy has sharpened because of the latest embargo legislation the helms-burton act it allows american citizens who were cuban nationals before the 1959 communist revolution to sue in u.s. courts foreign companies or individuals who `` traffic '' in property confiscated by the government of president fidel castro the law also allows u.s. visas to be denied to shareholders and officers of foreign firms operating these properties in cuba the law was enacted when anti-castro sentiment was runnning high in washington after cuban mig fighters last february shot down two light planes belonging to a miami-based cuban exile group killing all four people aboard speaking before the vote a vice-president of cuba 's ruling council of state carlos lage davila said the time had come for a new united states policy towards his country `` electoral tensions have already come to an end in this country president william clinton has been re-elected ... we believe the time has also come for a new u.s. policy toward cuba '' he said alluding to one of clinton 's favourite election images the need to build `` a bridge to the 21st century '' he asked `` how can a bridge into the future be built if it is not possible to lay a much shorter bridge -- just 90 miles long over which peace in the hemisphere may cross '' -- a reference to the distance between cuba and the united states ambassador victor marrero of the united states said cuba was the only western hemisphere country `` ruled by a regime that clings to the discredited dictatorial habits of the past '' ignoring the hopes of its people and international standards of human rights the united states like every other country had the right to `` choose with whom it trades to protect the property rights of its own citizens and to pursue its national interests '' the embargo provided `` important leverage to promote peaceful change in cuba '' he added ambassador john campbell of ireland speaking on behalf of the european union which recently decided to make it illegal for its members to comply with the helms-burton act criticised `` increasing violations of civil and political rights '' by the cuban government in the past year but he reiterated eu opposition to `` attempts by the united states to coerce other countries into complying with the commercial measures it has adopted unilaterally against cuba ''

yugoslavia hopes to soon set up free trade regimes with bosnia and croatia just as it did with macedonia last month making the first steps towards a regional customs union the daily nasa borba said on thursday `` on yugoslavia 's part there are no obstacles for such cooperation to be renewed as soon as possible '' yugoslav prime minister radoje kontic was quoted by the paper as saying kontic referred to cooperation with `` old partners in bosnia-herzegovina not only in the bosnian serb republic but also in the moslem-croat federation '' kontic said the creation of a free trade zone with macedonia had opened prospects for reviving full cooperation and that he expected certain free trade regimes `` comparatively soon '' with croatia as well `` the establishing of economic cooperation on the territory of former yugoslavia is inevitable '' kontic said yugoslavia and macedonia abolished trade tariffs on most goods produced in the two countries exempt are strategic yugoslav agricultural products and livestock and certain macedonian ferrous metallurgy products cigarettes buses and refrigerators which remain on quotas some independent analysts earlier this month described the move as the first step towards a regional trade union but milojko arsic of the centre for economic studies cesmekon said an ex-yugoslav regional free trade zone was too narrow and would not contribute greatly to economic recovery `` although it could be stimulative to raising production it would not be a generator of economic growth since we will probably never achieve the volume of trade we had before the breakup of former yugoslavia '' arsic told reuters -- amra kevic belgrade newsroom +381 11 2224305
