new jersey treasurer brian clymer still fully supports a proposed 2.9 billion taxable pension obligation bond deal despite a report published thursday detailing an alternate plan a spokeswoman said `` we are 100 percent doing this '' mary lou murphy a spokeswoman for the treasurer said in a telephone interview the bergen record reported on thursday that clymer had aired a `` new pension fund plan '' during an interview with the newspaper 's editors and reporters the report said clymer told the newspaper that the state legislature will allow the adminstration to avoid making about 647 million of payments into the pension system even if it does not approve the 2.9 billion pension bond deal skipping the payments is one of the key reasons the administration proposed the bond deal in the first place but murphy said the comments were about `` a hypothetical '' budget scenario and not meant to imply the treasurer is devising alternatives in the event the legislature rejects the bonds lawmakers including some republican allies of gov christine whitman has said they believe the bond sale is too large and fiscally irresponsible merrill lynch co inc is the senior manager on the proposed deal -- steven dickson 212-859-1652

china looks set to replace japan as the biggest source of u.s. trade deficits and commercial frictions that washington may find far more difficult to resolve trade analysts say the commerce department reported this week that for the first time the u.s. trade deficit with china in june surpassed the shortfall with japan economists said they expect china to top the monthly list periodically in the future as the u.s. shortfall with japan shrinks and the imbalance with china grows `` in the long term china is going to be our no 1 problem '' said norwest corp. chief economist sung won sohn `` and the problem with china is that they operate by a completely different set of rules the concept of a free and open market is alien to them '' u.s. secretary of commerce mickey kantor blamed the shortfall on closed markets and chinese trade policies that maximize exports while limiting imports kantor said he did not expect to see a deficit this year with china much higher than the 34 billion shortfall last year but that the administration was not happy with the trend `` because of discrimination against u.s. goods in the chinese market we need to make more progress '' he said `` we need to make our trade agreements work '' the united states and china moved to the brink of a trade war earlier this year over what washington said was beijing 's failure to enforce a 1995 agreement to protect copyrights and other intellectual property from rampant piracy the dispute was resolved when china promised to beef up enforcement trade analysts say they expect to see more such disputes with china as washington presses beijing to open markets to more u.s. good and even out the balance of trade the united states they said has some leverage in those disputes because it represents china 's largest market but they also argue that beijing 's leverage is growing as the united states becomes more dependent on china as an inexpensive source of a growing variety of consumer goods including textiles shoes toys and electronics in the long run analysts said it is in the interest of the united states for china to join the world trade organization wto beijing wants to join the global trade system as a developing nation that would enjoy more lenient rules washington noting the huge size of the chinese economy has objected and insisted china join the world body on more commercially acceptable terms analysts said it is also in the long-term interest of china to join the global trading body if it wants to continue to attract foriegn investment and be assured of continued access to u.s. markets `` in order for china to attract foreign investment at the levels it must in order to continue to grow and deal with the demands of a huge populace it has to be a full member of the global trading system '' said david rothkopf a former commerce department official but kenneth dewoskin a china expert at the university of michigan said the chinese may have lost interest -- at least for now -- in joining the global trading forum because of the cost in terms of economic reforms that would be required in order to become a member and because they no longer fear losing u.s most favored nation status during this year 's debate on china 's mfn a number of key lawmakers made clear they would like to end the annual ritual and make the status permanent next year the mfn status allows chinese goods to enter the country at the same low tariffs granted most other trading nations `` the big benefit of joining the wto is access to the north american market -- and they have that -- and slighly improved access to europe and japan '' dewoskin said `` but the cost is very high ''

turkish state minister ahmet cemil tunc will go to iraq at the weekend at the invitation of iraqi oil minister amir muhammad rasheed his press office said on thursday it said tunc would also meet iraqi president saddam hussein foreign minister mohammed saeed al-sahaf trade minister mohammed mehdi saleh and several other officials during his visit on march 30-april 4 tunc will be accompanied by several officials from the energy transport and housing ministries it said his office did not give details on the contents of the visit but a press official said the talks would `` dwell on bilateral economic and energy matters '' turkey 's state oil refinery tupras has a contract to lift 75,000 barrels per day of iraqi crude from baghdad 's u.n.-controlled sales under an oil-for-food deal last week some turkish companies began selling pulses and vegetable oil to iraq as the first shipments of food items under the u.n. deal rasheed came to turkey in december and discussed several projects between the two neighbours including one on iraq 's gas sales to turkey through a pipeline after an exploration of gas fields in iraq by turkish oil company tpao pipeline concern botas and the iraqi government -- ankara newsroom 90-312-4462940

senate republicans moved within striking distance of winning their top political goal a balanced budget amendment to the u.s. constitution with the pledge on tuesday of a key democrat to back it louisiana freshman sen. mary landrieu said she will keep her campaign pledge and vote for the republican-authored version despite reservations eyes then shifted to the lone undecided vote of freshman democrat robert torricelli of new jersey who could decide the outcome of the amendment he refused to comment saying he would announce his decision on wednesday torricelli voted for a similar amendment in the house of representatives in 1995 the amendment has the support of all 55 republicans and nine democrats with two more joe biden of delaware and max baucus of montana expected to vote for it as they did last year it needs 67 votes to reach the two-thirds requirement speaking to reporters landrieu said she preferred two less restrictive democratic alternatives but would vote for the republican version to keep a campaign pledge to vote for a balanced budget amendment `` based on many statements made during the campaign on this issue i will cast a 'yes vote but with reservations '' she said at a news conference landrieu was elected by a very narrow margin and the senate rules committee is looking into allegations of fraud raised by her opponent woody jenkins a fiscal conservative and former state treasurer landrieu said she would not have voted for the republican version if not for her campaign pledge `` i know a lot more about the subject now than i did during the campaign '' she said president bill clinton opposes the balanced budget amendment but landrieu 's decision was not criticised by the white house `` i think she made a principled decision based on what she felt was in the best interests of her constituents ... it 's obviously going to be a very close vote and we will continue to work hard to express our point of view '' white house spokesman mike mccurry said sen. tom daschle the leader of minority democrats who had spoken optimistically of defeating the amendment now raised concerns `` my momentum has lost a couple of wheels '' he told reporters after landrieu 's news conference one vote would swing the outcome either way with torricelli 's decision still unannounced republican leader trent lott of mississippi did not declare victory `` the vote is not over until it is actually taken i think there may still be some other senators who are wrestling with this though they have not said so publicly ''

the hungarian government approved the draft 1997 budget and decided to cut state expenditures by 10 billion forints 63.52 million this year finance minister peter medgyessy announced on thursday according to the draft which is to be submitted to parliament on monday hungary plans to reduce inflation and the budget deficit and widen the base of social security contributions medgyessy told a news conference hungary plans to push average annual inflation down to 18 percent next year compared with the latest official forecast of 22 to 24 percent for 1996 the country targets a general government deficit of 390 billion forints or 4.9 percent of the gross domestic product gdp for next year which is not comparable to this year 's four percent projection as the accounting system of the state debt will change from 1997 medgyessy said `` in a comparative structure the 4.9 percent corresponds to three percent '' the minister told a conference of local municipalities on wednesday adding that the change was technical and did not demand economic policy action the planned accounting change means that the devaluation losses on hungary 's foreign state debt will appear in the state budget from next year instead of the national bank of hungary 's books as to the current practice budget expenditures will be curbed by increasing subsidies to state agencies by only 15 percent and to local municipalities by 13 percent in 1997 compared with the 18 percent inflation target medgyessy said hungary will begin the reform of social security contributions in 1997 so as to break the social security budget even next year he said adding that the latest offical forecast for the 1996 social security deficit for 1996 was 53 billion forints this was up from the 17.8 billion original target and some 40 billion forints in 1995 medgyessy said the government decided to save 10 billion forints from this year 's central state budget expenditures to plug the gap of the social security funds with the cuts which will affect state agencies hungary expects to keep the deficit of the general government including the central budget and state funds at four percent of the gdp as agreed with the international monetary fund hungary plans to widen next year the field of those revenues upon which social security contribution is paid and introduce a minimum social security contribution revenues will be increased by these measures and that enables hungary to reduce social security contributions paid by employers to 41 percent from the current 42.5 percent medgyessy said he added the cut was smaller than the previously planned 2.5 percent but from july 1997 the government will introduce further reduction if the state of the social security budget justifies that the registration system of the healthcare fund will be modernized from a world bank loan and 1.2 billion forints to be provided by the state and the government expects the fund to tighten control on revenue collection medgyessy said -- budapest newsroom 36 1 327 4040 1=157.42 forint

the polish senate 's decision to cut personal income tax levels next year by one point reduces uncertainty over the probable 1997 budget deficit now likely to be near this year 's 2.8 percent of gross domestic product gdp the senate on thursday amended the lower house 's income tax bill and introduced levels at 20 32 and 44 percent in 1997 slightly higher than those proposed by the government and defeated in the lower house late last month deputy finance minister waldemar manugiewicz told reuters that if the senate decision came into force the government would amend its current budget draft to accommodate lower tax revenues and a higher deficit of about 2.8 percent of gdp `` if the senate 's decision becomes law then obviously the deficit will increase by about 850-900 million zlotys to 2.8 percent of gdp from 2.6 percent assumed by the current draft '' manugiewicz said he said budget expenditures would remain unchanged and the higher deficit would be financed by increased revenues from privatisation of banks and sales of government paper abroad he also said some of the cash left in consumers pockets due to lower taxes would return to the treasury 's coffers as indirect taxes such as value added tax vat and excise tax the senate amendments now return to the lower house which can either adopt them or uphold its proposal for a four-level tax scale granting sharp tax cuts for people on low incomes which the government has deemed economically unsound if the lower house were to reaffirm this four-level scale president aleksander kwasniewski linked to the ruling coalition 's larger party the democratic left alliance sld has suggested he would veto the bill his veto would in effect keep the present 21- 33- and 45-percent tax levels intact and the 1997 budget unchanged from the government draft now being debated in parliament which assumes no tax cuts and a deficit of 2.6 percent of gdp but the senate amendments appear set to survive the lower house vote after the main opposition party the union for freedom indicated it would support them along with the sld `` i confirm that the union for freedom will vote in favour of this scale '' party chairman leszek balcerowicz said last month uw deputies joined other opposition members and the co-ruling polish peasant party psl to push through the four-level tax scale a move that stunned the government with the uw the sld which backed the one-point tax reduction can muster more than the 50 percent of votes in the lower house needed to uphold the senate decision finance minister grzegorz kolodko welcomed the senate vote saying the amended bill fit in broadly with government plans -- warsaw newsroom +48 22 653 9700

proposals to bail out countries pushed by almost unpayable debts into deepening poverty are so rigid that very few stand much hope of help before the turn of the century the commonwealth said in a confidential report obtained by reuters on tuesday and on the top of the agenda at this week 's meeting of commonwealth finance ministers in this caribbean island the group argues that the international community have imposed too many rules `` these restrictions reduce to only 11 the number of countries likely to receive multilateral debt relief and delay relief so that only three will receive comprehensive treatment '' it said several of the 53 members of the commonwealth which groups memebrs of the former british empire are saddled with large debts to multilateral financial institutions such as the international monetary fund imf and world bank historically the poorer countries have been forced to borrow from these institutions whose industrial nation shareholders only recently agreed to even consider writing off some of the debt by contrast major developing countries such as in latin america were able to borrow from commercial banks with whom they subsequently rescheduled defaulted debt payments into far easier terms britain has been pressing for greater help including selling some of the imf 's 40 billion in gold reserves to release funds for the heavily indebted poor countries the issue will be one of the main topics at next week 's annual imf/world bank meeting in washington when industrial countries will come under further pressure to do more to help the poor `` in theory up to 20 countries are eligible for debt relief but in reality they are focusing on only two or three '' one commonwealth official said `` the proposals currently being developed need considerable strengthening if they are to have a decisive impact on the multilateral debt problems of heavily indebted poor countries '' the report said adding that it welcomed steps taken thus far the report which commonwealth sources said had input from the british treasury said the criteria and time-frame for countries to join in any relief scheme were too restrictive for example a country has to have a proven three-year economic track record before individual creditor countries will help and another three after that before the multilateral financial agencies step in the question of the imf selling some of its gold has yet to be resolved after two years of debate with countries such as germany fiercely opposed to selling what they see as the imf 's family jewels last week the imf 's board put off any decision on the sale of gold until consensus could be reached financing the relief is also open to doubt the report said that the imf and world bank estimate the cost of the initiative would be 5.6 billion of which they will only provide 2 billion it urged that the criteria be changed so that as many countries as possible get relief by 2000 and that it is funded fairly among all the creditors and not shouldered by budget- conscious industrial countries -- bermuda newsroom +1 441 238-8000 reuter jwt

the bank of japan boj may alter its monetary policy before assessing the possible economic impact of a planned rise in the consumption tax in april a senior boj official was quoted as saying by the nikkei financial daily on thursday the official who is in charge of policy-making at the central bank said `` the economy is stronger than we anticipated '' `` it is possible that the boj may decide to alter monetary policy before examining the impact from a planned consumption tax increase '' the senior boj official added `` i wonder why the market assessment of the economy has been so weak '' the newspaper is widely read by traders and financial institutions the official 's remarks signalling a possible early rise in japanese interest rates was one factor behind the dollar 's steep slide against the yen in early tokyo trading on thursday currency traders said -- -tokyo treasury desk +81-3-3432-8676

philippine merchandise exports in january rose to 1.688 billion up 18.8 percent from 1.420 billion in the same period last year the national statistics office said on tuesday manufactured goods which account for the bulk of exports rose in january to 1.433 billion up 21.4 percent from 1.180 billion in january 1995 manufactured goods exports were dominated by electronics and components which accounted for 732.86 million up from 559.71 million in the same period last year almost a third of the shipments of electronics and components had gone to the united states the national statistics office said another component of the manufactured goods sector apparel and clothing accesories showed lower exports in january compared to last year income from apparel and clothing accessories fell to 144.29 million from 197.54 million in january 1996 -- manila newsroom 632 841 8934

the german bundesbank will have no grounds to raise interest rates any time soon and may even have scope to lower credit costs further this economic cycle a member of the bank 's policy-making council said on tuesday olaf sievert president of the regional central bank based in the east german city of leipzig also said in a speech he believed worries that currency markets could be very turbulent in the run-up to european monetary union were exaggerated speaking at a reception in leipzig sievert said `` i see nothing which could give us grounds to take a firmer grip on the monetary reins '' he added that it was hard to say whether there could be scope for further cuts in leading interest rates this cycle the bundesbank has held its lombard and discount rates steady since april but it reduced a key money market rate in august `` whether there is room to manoeuvre on the downside remains to be seen '' he said according to the text of his speech which was released in advance sievert said the outlook for german inflation continued to be favourable despite increases in raw materials prices `` the prospects for the future also look good '' he said noting annual german inflation is now running at around 1.4 percent this fact together with expectations that money supply growth will slow in 1997 meant that the bundesbank did not have to be too concerned about the fact that m3 money supply growth overshot the central bank 's target in 1996 he said `` the overshooting of the goal is no reason for considerable concern given that the pace of money supply growth had already started to slow last spring '' he said good news for the economy lay in the fact that the excessive appreciation in the mark seen in 1995 when the dollar tumbled to an all-time low had corrected `` the appreciation of the mark seen in spring 1995 which was absolutely unfitting for the real economy has in the meantime been corrected '' sievert said the likelihood of further currency market turbulence ahead of the planned creation of the euro in 1999 also seemed smaller than many feared he said adding that he did not expect this to be a major problem over the next two years looking ahead to possible problems sievert said `` i am not thinking here so much of the widespread fear that speculative trends on financial markets could create turbulence which will make the task of monetary policy more difficult '' `` there are possibbly exaggerated worries here '' he added growing consensus in financial markets that european monetary union emu would start on time in 1999 meant that any speculation was more likely to be `` stabilising speculation and not destabilising speculation '' `` that is in any case true for the internal relationship between the currency areas which will form a single currency area from the start of monetary union '' sievert added he added that it would be more difficult to ensure stable relationships between currencies which entered emu and those initially left outside countries which wish to merge their currencies in the euro from 1999 onward must meet goals on public deficits public debt interest rates exchange rates and inflation this year in his text sievert also dismissed a french proposal to create a `` stability council '' as a political counterweight to the future european central bank this proposal appeared to be a meaningless attempt to find some form of mediator for monetary policy which had the clearly defined role of price stability as its absolute priority noting that the council in contrast to the ecb itself would have no real decision-making power he added `` but why then bother with such a council at all '' -- frankfurt newsroom +49 69 756525

the french cabinet will select two members of the bank of france 's monetary policy council in early january because the outgoing council has not yet given its opinion on the nominees government sources said on tuesday the mandates of journalist jean boissonnat and banker bruno de maulde expire on january 6 the cabinet holds its last session of the year on wednesday and the matter is not on the agenda the sources said the next cabinet session is scheduled for january 3 `` it will probably be at the very beginning of the year '' a government source said `` we are reaching the end of the procedure but the bank of france has to give its opinion on the six candidates and to our knowledge we have not yet received it '' the source said a member of the monetary policy council confirmed to reporters that the body had not yet discussed the issue sources familiar with the process said earlier that national assembly president philippe seguin senate president rene monory and economic and social council ces head jean matteoli failed to agree on a list of nominees and would submit separate lists the sources said the main disagreement was between monory an ardent pro-european and seguin who campaigned against the maastricht treaty in a 1992 referendum before converting and favours a weaker franc and faster interest rate cuts the possible replacement of the two has unnerved financial markets on fears the government might use it as an excuse to try and soften the bank 's policy on interest rates -- paris newsroom +331 4221 5452

poland has already exhausted reserves within this year 's budget to cover additional outflows stemming from higher finacing costs the head of the finance ministry 's public debt department said on wednesday piotr dziewulski said high market rates and yields of comparable nbp-bills have pushed up yields on polish treasuries above expected levels and increased financing costs `` after five months it is difficult to say ... but there should not be any savings on the costs of financing the public deficit this year ... as high rates alrady devoured reserves '' he told a news conference in 1996 poland had significant savings in financing the budget deficit which eventually reduced its budget gap to 2.4 percent of the gross domestic product from the planned 2.8 percent of gdp `` we planned to have yields around 19 percent early in the year and now we have yields at 21 to 21.5 percent depending on the maturity of the paper '' he said dziewulski again said that public sales of polish bonds have been below expectations as many individuals were not interested in purchasing the paper because it was no longer tax-deductible he said the non-banking sector 's share in financing the budget deficit was satisfactory -- warsaw newsroom +48 22 653 9700

thailand 's consumer price index rose 4.3 percent year-on-year in april the thai commerce ministry said on thursday analysts said the figure was better than expected as they had forecast inflation would rise about 4.5 to 4.6 percent on an annualised basis `` that 's a good number '' said one analyst who had predicted 4.6 percent inflation which rose 0.2 percent on a monthly basis in april was 4.5 percent year-on-year in march the commerce ministry said wholesale prices rose 0.9 percent year-on-year in april compared with a 1.1 percent increase the previous month among consumer prices rice and meat products were the biggest price gainers in the month the ministry said there was no immediate market reaction to the announcement since markets were closed on thursday for a labour day holiday the current trend shows thai inflation for the year should come in below the 1996 figure of 5.9 percent

new zealand treasurer and deputy prime minister winston peters said on thursday an improvement in the merchandise trade surplus for the third quarter in a row revealed in december quarter balance of payments data was `` very encouraging '' `` the government is keen to see this trend continue '' peters said through a spokesman `` today 's figures confirm the government 's view that the economy is on the right track '' peters also noted that the current account deficit to gdp ratio which came in a 4.2 percent for the year to december 31 was better than market expectations statistics new zealand earlier on thursday said new zealand 's merchandise trade surlus was nz 40 million in the december 1996 quarter up from a 317 million deficit in the september 1996 quarter snz said the december quarter current account deficit was 1.29 billion and the december annual current account deficit was 3.91 billion -- wellington newsroom 64 4 4734746

british prime minister tony blair wrapped up a hectic two days of diplomacy on friday confident that europe was heeding his message that economic reform to tackle mass unemployment can be delayed no longer buoyed by an opinion poll at home showing that within five weeks of taking power he was the most popular prime minister on record blair made it clear after talks in bonn with german chancellor helmut kohl that he wanted to use his honeymoon to re-establish britain as a leading player on the european stage `` what is important for us to understand as a country is that people are looking to britain to give some leadership in what are very difficult times in europe `` people like the idea of a britain that is constructive and is setting the agenda '' blair told reporters after two hours of talks with kohl that british officials called friendly and constructive the labour prime minister pressed on kohl the same message he had delivered at a meeting of europe 's centre-left parties in the southern swedish city of malmo new economic times and europe 's 18 million jobless require governments to come up with new solutions blair said he believed his mantra of flexible markets was striking a chord -- even in a country like germany whose successful social market economic model relies on a degree of state intervention that would be anathema in new labour britain `` i was delighted that there was a very strong measure of agreement between myself and chancellor kohl that we do require economic reform in europe '' blair said `` people know it 's a different type of economy today and we have to focus on education technology developing small businesses -- not the old state intervention of the 60s '' he added blair 's aides said he received a similarly positive response from leaders of countries such as sweden denmark portugal and the netherlands during the malmo congress and although blair would not go along with some of the ideas of french prime minister lionel jospin -- who said in malmo that unfettered market forces would threaten civilisation as we know it -- he was content that the new french premier also wanted to put jobs at the top of the european agenda blair 's advice to kohl on economic reform was particularly telling on a day that another rise in german unemployment dealt a fresh blow to the chancellor 's cherished hopes of qualifying for the european union 's planned single currency but blair who ended 18 years of conservative rule in a landslide victory on may 1 denied that it was presumptuous of him to come and lecture kohl europe 's elder statesman and other much more experienced leaders `` it 's not a question of lecturing but it is a question of saying to people come on let 's face the common challenges that we have in our countries everyone can see the problems that europe has -- particularly the high levels of unemployment '' he said `` it 's in our interests that europe succeeds with britain as a leading player in it '' he added blair said he was very pleased that kohl had expressed his strong personal commitment to the four-nation eurofighter project which has been dogged by germany 's deepening budget problems he also believed that kohl now understood better britain 's insistence on retaining control over its borders as part of the revised eu treaty due to be concluded at a summit in amsterdam on june 16-17 `` britain is an island we have a particuar view on our frontiers and our borders and that is absolutely unchangeable for us now i hope that everyone in europe understands that and i think they do '' he said

argentina collected 236 million in income tax and 105 million in personal wealth levies in 1996 national tax service dgi head carlos silvani said tuesday silvani told reporters that the figures could not be compared with 1995 data because this year individuals who have a partnership in a company are only due to pay their income and personal wealth tax by may `` making a comparison is very difficult '' he said last week was the deadline for collection of the two annual taxes despite the change in the deadline for individuals who have a partnership in a company making comparisons difficult silvani said he was optimistic tax collection was going well `` i think we have enough facts to say that things are going well '' he told reporters he anticipated another 100,000 income tax statements and at least 15 percent more personal wealth statements will have been submitted by the time the may deadline runs out -- axel bugge buenos aires newsroom +541 318-0668

trade ministers scrambled on wednesday to reach an accord aimed at cutting tariffs on information technology while struggling to reconcile deep-seated differences over workers rights negotiators from the united states and the european union scheduled another round of meetings on the sidelines of a 128-nation trade conference in singapore to settle their remaining disagreements over the outline of an information technology agreement ita after meeting in four closed-door sessions on tuesday `` there is not an agreement yet '' european union trade commissioner sir leon brittan said on wednesday after meeting acting u.s. trade representative charlene barshefsky `` there is agreement on many points there are some outstanding ones we are trying to resolve those '' brittan said the united states with strong backing from japan is keen to see an accord to free up trade in the 600 billion market for computers software chips and other high-technology products by the year 2000 before the end of this week 's first ministerial meeting of the world trade organisation wto `` there is no question that what the industrialised countries now hope for most here is a deal on information technology products and agreement to work hard for a basic telecommunications pact by february '' said one key negotiator the big four trade powers -- the united states the eu japan and canada -- hope to settle their differences in particular over the touchy question of product coverage before meeting again later on wednesday with other nations interested in joining the infotech accord `` they the big four are still fighting some working-level negotiators of some countries are getting crazy '' a japanese givernment source told reuters `` i am hopeful we will reach a consensus before the afternoon meeting starts '' developing countries were shown a draft outline late on tuesday of an accord worked out by the big four but the draft did not specify product coverage or spell out what sort of flexibility could be shown to developing countries on the timing of the tariff cuts the japanese source said progress on the infotech deal looked less elusive than on the contentious issue of whether the 128-nation wto set up in 1995 as the successor to the general agreement on tariffs and trade should get involved in enforcing labour standards the united states with strong backing from france and norway says that without action to tackle the exploitation of child labour and eradicate sweatshop conditions in the third world support for free trade in rich countries will evaporate diplomats said that washington digging in its heels had repeated a threat to reject other parts of the meeting 's final declaration to be published on friday unless it won mention of the labour issue poorer countries are equally adamant in rejecting a scrutiny role for the wto they say attempts to impose workplace rules is protectionism in disguise because the trade advantages their cheap labour gives them would be whittled away on wednesday malaysia again rejected the attempts to put labour rights on the official wto agenda `` the debate on the issue of labour standards has indeed proven to be a divisive factor rafidah aziz malaysia 's international trade and industry minister said in a speech `` we reject any move to discuss and deliberate labour standards and other social clauses in the wto '' rafidah said bill jordon secretary-general of the international confederation of free trade unions icftu told a news conference he was hopeful some compromise could be reached but said it might take the form of a statement asking the wto director-general to take up the issue with his counterpart at the international labour organisation ilo `` i am hopeful that the two extremes of this argument can find a place within one statement '' jordan said `` i did not expect the wto to take on board all that we want ... what we want them to do is to recognise their responsibility in the process of the globalisation of trade '' delegates have meanwhile been edging towards consensus on textiles and agriculture as well as over how the world trade body should tackle government procurement investment rules and domestic competition policy

reserve bank of new zealand rbnz governor don brash said on tuesday he would like a new mix of lower foreign exchange rates and higher interest rates to take the economy forward since january 1993 the currency has risen more than 40 percent against the u.s. dollar advancing from us 0.5010 to as high as us 0.7170 in november 1996 `` i 'd be much happier with a somewhat lower exchange rate and somewhat higher interest rates '' said brash in an interview with reuters financial television rftv `` we 've had a very strong rise in exchange rates and a fall in interest rates now i 'd prefer to see a different combination -- somewhat lower exchange rates and somewhat higher interest rates '' brash said new zealand 's strong currency has hit exporters particularly hard and put pressure on the new centre-right national-new zealand first coalition to curb spending plans the rbnz does not set interest rates administratively like most central banks of industrialised countries but relies on regulating the amount of cash in the system brash added `` we can be happy with a lower currency if we have higher interest rates and vice versa '' asked to give an optimum level for the new zealand dollar he said `` the best level for the currency is the level which delivers ongoing price stability at this point we look as though this will be achieved '' the new zealand dollar was trading at us 0.6970 by 1304 gmt compared with us 0.6950 at the wellington close on tuesday brash repeated the central bank 's view inflation would fall below 1.0 percent next year then rise through 1999 to 2000 `` the biggest single factor in the second half of this year particularly is the delayed response of new zealand prices to the rise in the exchange rate which we 've seen over the last two or three years '' he said although the inflation target band was increased last year to zero-to-3.0 percent from zero-to-2.0 percent brash said `` i 'd be very disappointed indeed if we went above 3.0 percent '' if inflation did go above the 3.0 percent target he said he would reconsider his position as governor `` whenever we go outside the target over the top or under the bottom i look very carefully at my position and so does the board '' he said in terms of gross domestic product data brash said he was as surprised as many analysts were by the strength of the december quarter when the economy grew 0.7 percent `` we were expecting gdp in the march 97 quarter to be up by only some 2.0 percent over the march 96 quarter and in fact it looks at this stage as though it might be slightly stronger '' he said -- international bonds unit +44 171 542 6137

thailand 's new government on wednesday detailed major policy initiatives to tackle the slowing national economy but economic analysts said the proposals were vague prime minister chavalit yongchaiyudh who took office earlier this month vowed in a speech to parliamnent to uphold fiscal discipline reduce spending deregulate the financial sector and stimulate the slowing economy chavalit 's heads a six-party coalition government that replaced the administration of previous premier banharn silpa-archa banharn was accused of economic mismanagement analysts said the government had identified key economic woes afflicting the nation but had left markets and investors hungry for details on strategies and implementation `` anyone can present policy like that it 's too vague at least there should be more details to assure us that the policy will be implemented in the right direction '' said arporn chewakriengkrai chief economist at deutsche morgan grenfell `` on fiscal discipline for example the government should have at least spelt out that it will not allow fiscal deficits instead of just saying it will uphold fiscal discipline '' she said arporn also said the government had failed to spell out its policies on the direction it wants interest rates to take and on the future of the baht and the system under which it is fixed daily the government pledged that it would curb the current account gap which the central bank expects to rise up to 8.3 percent of gross domestic product gdp this year by boosting savings and foreign exchange earnings and reducing spending thailand 's exports the country 's growth engine during the past decade recorded the slowest growth in years in 1996 growing just 0.9 percent in the first nine months against 20 percent during the same period last year the government also vowed to develop thai money and capital markets to boost regional competitiveness and to deregulate the financial sector maintain price stability and revive the depressed property sector thailand 's stock market is now at a three-year low as many foreign investors have left to invest elsewhere in the region following a year of political uncertainty `` the overall picture looked fine the government seemed to address the problems we are facing but it should give us some hints on its measures and action plans '' said somjai phagaphasvivat a professor at thammsart university somjai said wednesday 's announcement painted some contradictory pictures `` the government needed to tell us how to curb the current account deficit while at the same time seeking to expand various capital-intensive infrastructure projects '' he said

poland 's 1997 gross domestic product gdp is expected to slow to 5.4 percent from an estimated 5.6 percent in 1996 and seven percent in 1995 according to the independent think tank gdansk institute the think tank also said on thursday it expected gdp to further slow to 4.8 percent in 1998 the private institute for market economy research ibngr also said december 1997 year-on-year inflation was likely to ease to 15 to 16 percent rather than to the government 's forecast of 13 percent forecast that drop would be from 18.5 percent inflation in december 1996 gdansk said it expected a higher rate of inflation than the government mainly because domestic consumption seen in the 40-percent boom of credit for the non-financial sector last year was growing quicker than gdp `` last year was good for the polish economy but not good enough to create foundations for a big leap forward which poland needs to catch up with western europe '' ibngr president janusz dabrowski told a news conference `` we will see a stabilisation of economic indices in the coming years '' he said dabrowski expected 1997 growth to continue being fuelled by domestic demand and investment despite an expected easing in these two areas from last year 's nine and 18.7 percent respectively last year demand and investment replaced exports expansion as the main catalyst for poland 's economic growth in 1996 exports growth declined to 6.1 percent from 18.4 percent in 1995 imports imports grew 20.1 percent against 22.7 percent in 1995 the drop in exports growth was a result of weak economic performance in western countries and of zloty appreciation the central bank allowed the zloty to rise to contain the 1995 inflationary boom from currency reverves dabrowski said slower exports growth led to a widening trade deficit to more than 8 billion last year from nearly 2 billion in 1995 ibngr 's analyst miroslaw gronicki said though the economic recovery in the west should lift poland 's exports next year the trade gap was still likely to rise to 14 billion in 1997 and to 15.3 billion in 1998 he said the ballooning trade gap would no longer be sufficiently offset by cross-border retail trade which brings in about 6 billion annually and foreign investment inflows the higher deficit may gradually cut currency reserves which would pressure the zloty and undermine anti-inflationary policies he said but `` the zloty is unlikely to stay strong considering the worsening of the deficit '' granicki said he added the dollar was likely to cost about 3.35-3.4 zlotys at the end of 1997 he also said that meeting the 13-percent inflation target in 1997 would require much smaller than planned wage increases especially for pensioners and public workers which was unlikely in the year of parliamentary elections on the other hand the expected high agricultural output in 1997 would help fight inflation he said -- warsaw newsroom +48 22 653 9700

the u.s. economy picked up steam in june according to economic reports released friday fuelled by a jump in orders for big-ticket items such as cars and appliances durable goods orders far surpassed most economists forecasts while a separate report on sales of existing homes showed the housing market though off slightly still keeping pace with its recent strong levels june durable goods orders jumped 2.3 percent the strongest showing since a 3.4 percent gain in january economists surveyed by reuters had forecast a 1.4 percent rise in durables orders `` the first half of the year ended on an upbeat note setting the stage for a strong second half for the nation 's manufacturing sector '' said ken mayland chief economist at keycorp `` the goods-producing side of the economy is really humming '' many experts had underestimated orders for transportation-related equipment which account for about 20 percent of total durable goods orders the transportation goods component surged 7.5 percent last month helping to boost the overall figure while the report reflected increased economic activity the treasury market quickly shook off any fears of an overheating economy the benchmark 30-year treasury bond dipped briefly after the durable goods report was released but then rebounded to stand a touch higher its yield which moves in the opposition direction of its price was at 6.44 percent unchanged from thursday non-defence capital goods orders a more forward-looking measure of companies expansion plans were particularly impressive in june said tim o'neill chief economist at harris bank/bank of montreal orders for capital goods excluding defence-related equipment jumped 5.4 percent in june that compared with a 1.1 percent gain in may and a 1.7 percent decline in april `` the non-defence capital goods orders are one important bellwether of the confidence of producers in the sustainability of growth in the economy '' o'neill said he projected third-quarter economic growth of between 3.0 percent and 3.5 percent following more tepid expansion in the second quarter the existing home sales report offered somewhat mixed signals the national association of realtors said purchases of existing homes fell 2.6 percent to an annual rate of 4.14 million units as both housing prices and mortgage interest rates picked up wall street economists had projected a somewhat smaller decline but a coinciding drop in home inventories suggested the housing market remains firm `` today 's report is just a minor blip '' said john park an economist at sanwa securities usa co. `` we should definitely start seeing the housing sector pick up steam in the third quarter '' according to the nar report home inventories declined to six months worth of homes in june from may 's 6.8 months indicating strong demand the inventory levels were somewhat favourable said anthony chan chief economist at banc one investment advisers of columbus ohio chan noted that any number below six months tends to be associated with heightened activity in the months ahead `` moving forward we may fall below six months '' chan said adding that the seasonally adjusted annual rate could climb above a 4.20-million-unit level in addition long-term interest rates moved lower in july which should provide stimulus for housing purchases and mortgage refinancings in the near term park said nar president russell booth said he expects the underlying housing market to remain stable in the immediate future `` while there has been a slight tapering off the market has remained strong due to favourable economic conditions overall '' booth said

the bank of england did not offer the uk money market an early round of assistance after forecasting a liquidity shortage of around 250 million stg

the average maturity of brazilian overseas issues crept up marginally in the third quarter of 1996 the central bank said in a statement the central bank said the average maturity of total overseas issues was 7.2 years against 7.0 years in the second quarter that compared with an average maturity of 4.1 years in the third quarter of 1995 the average spread remained stable across the two quarters at 465 basis points over u.s. treasuries versus 462 bps in the first quarter and 517 bps in the last quarter of 1995 the bank 's statement said the average global cost of the 77 brazilian issues in the third quarter totalling 3.735 billion was 11.28 percent a year there were no issues by the public sector and all the paper was placed by private financial and non-financial organizations with the non-financial sector enjoying cost and maturity advantages the average maturity of third quarter issues by banks was 5.8 years and the spread 525 bps the average maturity for issues by companies was 7.5 years with a spread of 443 bps -- michael christie brasilia newsroom 55-61-2230358

gov christie whitman on wednesday outlined a spending plan for new jersey in the fiscal year starting july 1 while spending is rising only 1.3 percent the budget contains small initiatives designed to please key constituencies bond raters thought the budget appreared reasonable steven hochman assistant director of state ratings at moody 's investors service said `` the economic assumptions appear to be reasonable their revenues to date in the current fiscal year are on target '' and the revenue projections for the next fiscal year appear to be reasonable hochman said however he noted `` we have questions about the non-recurring resources '' he cited the projected benefits of the proposed pension obligation bond program and the potential for budget relief `` that is an area we will be examining more closely '' he said moody 's rates the state 's general obligation bonds aa1 robin prunty a director with standard poor 's corp said the pension financing plan `` in and of itself '' would not cause the state 's rating to be downgraded s p rates the debt aa-plus she also added `` we are comfortable with thier use of non-recurring revenues '' environmentalists were pleased that the department of environmental protection will not lose any staff positions in the 1,235 job cuts she announced curtis fisher of the new jersey public interest reasearch group said he was pleased by a pilot project to operate 50 buses fueled by natural gas child advocates were pleased by her proposed health insurance plan for children who lack coverage children first will be a private-public partnership whitman said the utility industry was pleased by her plan to end the gross receipts and franchise tax but mayors and municipal managers were wary about the impact on state aid whitman defended the sale of 3.4 billion in bonds to liquidate unfunded liabilities in four state pension plans that will enable treasurer brian clymer to divert some of 2.3 billion in surplus cash in those funds to defray parts of the state 's annual contributions total expenditures will reach 16.4 billion up from a revised fy 1997 total of 16.2 billion the budget deals some bad news to local governments and to higher education -- state aid will remain the same it also calls for shedding 1,235 jobs with an estimated 735 by layoff clymer said that if historic patterns hold up actual layoffs will be about 320 the budget relies on two controversial gimmicks to achieve a comnfortable balance one would raise 200 million by selling the state 's temporary disability insurance plan which covers 2.4 million new jerseyans with a 105 payroll tax `` private firms already provide this insurance just as efficiently '' whitman said the second maneuver would have a bigger impact it would raise 3.4 billion by the sale of bonds to liquidate the unfunded liabilities in the four pension fdunds run on behalf of state county and local employees that would free up 2.3 billion in `` surplus '' -- capital not needed to cover current obligations clymer proposes to use some of those funds to reduce the state 's cash contribution to the funds by 269 million in the current budget and 354 million in the next he said wall street has no objection since it is merely an exchange of one form of debt for another -- u.s. municipal desk 212-859-1650

egypt 's foreign reserves stood at about 18.9 billion at the end of february slightly down on 19 billion at the end of 1996 an official source said on monday the figures are slightly distorted by a payment of 300 million to egypt 's paris club creditors during january disguising an underlying upward trend the source said egypt 's central bank has been buying dollars for pounds to sterilise large inflows of foreign capital destined for investment in treasury bills and the stock exchange the inflows have put upward pressure on the pound which has appreciated marginally on the interbank market despite an official policy of keeping the exchange rate stable 1 3.395 pounds -- cairo newsroom +20 2 578 3290/1

britain 's economy will achieve growth of more than three percent next year chancellor of the exchequer kenneth clarke said on wednesday `` it 's obviously on course for over three percent growth next year '' he said on bbc radio he said his decision to raise interest rates would have no impact on his november 26 budget `` it 's got nothing to do with the budget '' clarke said `` the budget is there to look after public finances i 'm going to set a budget that will keep us on course for a balanced budget over the medium-term '' clarke also said he was confident the government 's target of 2.5 percent for underlying inflation would be met retail prices excluding mortgage interest rates edged up to 2.9 percent year-on-year in september `` i 'm confident we will meet it '' he said -- mike peacock london newsroom +44 171 542 5109

tokyo stocks are unlikely to fall drastically and the japanese government wants the prices to move in a stable manner chief cabinet secretary seiroku kajiyama told a news conference on tuesday `` stocks remained soft but i have a feeling the price decline will not be very drastic ... i want a stable attitude in the market '' kajiyama said tokyo stocks struggled back up above the 20,000 level by midday tuesday after dipping below that key level earlier the first time the nikkei has been below 20,000 since march 15 brokers said at midday the benchmark nikkei 225 average was up 88.73 points or 0.44 percent to 20,195.84 off a low of 19,920.02 its september futures were up 60 points to 20,210

the european union will seek to become more competitive with the united states and canada in trade with mexico during free-trade negotiations with mexico next month the european union 's ambassador to mexico said in an interview `` right now we 're not in a good position to compete '' mexico 's jacques lecomte told reuters `` there 's the problem of duties that of the distance and the value of the u.s. dollar compared with the european currencies '' lecomte said mexico and the eu likely would start negotiations in the second half of october in a bid to free trade barriers small and medium-sized exporters stand to gain the most from such a deal `` the big businesses do n't need help '' lecomte said `` if they have problems with tariffs they can negotiate bilaterally trilaterally or globally it 's not that way for a small company '' mexican exports to the european union grew 20 percent in 1995 over 1994 to 3.38 billion according to mexican government statistics at the same time mexico imported 6.72 billion worth of goods from the european union the united states remained the most important trading partner for both mexico and the european union doing more than 120 billion in trade with mexico alone lecomte said an important part of the trade between mexico and the united states involves european comapanies he cited the example of german car-maker volkswagen ag which sells many of its mexican-made cars in the united states the mexican-european talks also will include the topic of battling drug traffickers lecomte said `` it 's a key element in economic and trade relations '' lecomte said -- mara luisa aguilar mexico city newsroom 525 728-9553

proposed changes in venezuela 's social security system got a lukewarm reception from business leaders on friday when union leaders formally presented their reform plans to the tripartite commission the commission gathers private sector leaders union and government officials in an attempt to break a long-standing impasse over social security reform -- seen as a prerequisite for a long awaited restructuring of the 1.2 million strong venezuelan public sector `` there are some matters in their proposal that worry us '' leading business chamber fedecamaras president jorge serrano told reporters under current rules fired workers are paid twice their monthly salary for each year worked while retiring workers are paid once government and private sector leaders say such a scheme prevents increases in worker salaries take home pay is boosted instead when needed with monthly bonds under changes proposed by venezuela 's largest union the confederation of venezuelan workers ctv workers would be paid severance payments according to a sliding scale workers on salaries less than 53,000 bolivars a month would receive three months salary for each year worked while those with salaries over 500,000 bolivars would receive one month 's pay ctv president federico ramirez leon said the scale favored those who are paid less `` which are most is this country '' but serrano said he favored moving towards a new system of social security payments rather than a tinkering of the current method -- oscar galvis caracas newsroom 582 505 2600

gaps remain between the european union eu and japan on aspects of a proposed deal to scrap tariffs on information technology products by 2000 but there may be room for flexibility a japanese government source told reporters on tuesday he was speaking after foreign minister yukihiko ikeda met eu trade commissioner sir leon brittan for about an hour `` we have not reached a compromise on non-tariff measures on product coverage we still have n't solved differences on sensitive items for quad members there may be some flexibility -- i do n't know '' the source said he said brittan and ikeda did not discuss the issue of china 's application to join the wto but added that brittan wanted to bring up the issue at the working lunch he added that the main issues at the working lunch would be the information technology agreement and the telecommunications negotiations but the source also said the infotech deal would be a key focus of a working lunch among the big four ministers on tuesday the four are the eu japan the united states and canada he added that the ministers were unlikely to reach an agreement at the lunch but might get close `` without instructions from the ministers it will be difficult to pull it together at the working level this afternoon '' he said he also said that brittan and ikeda discussed efforts to reach a wto agreement on telecoms services and that this issue seemed to moving towards resolution

alexandre lamfalussy president of the european monetary institute said on tuesday a stability pact for long-term compliance with budget and debt criteria in europe 's planned currency union was a good idea `` in this field the view is simple a stability pact would be very useful '' lamfalussy said adding it would be needed in the long run lamfalussy said the european monetary institute would not give specific advice to nations finance ministers but that it does extend its general blessing to such a pact `` the finance ministers are the ones who have to produce it the stability pact '' he said -- frankfurt newsroom 49 69 756525

new jersey 's surplus for fiscal 1997 is currently running at 550 million with stronger-than-expected revenues contributing to the windfall state officials said tuesday state treasurer brian clymer is set to review more details of new jersey 's cash position in legislative testimony wednesday but treasury officials offered a preview of the figures in an interview tuesday revenues collected in the first 10-months of the year totaled 13.2 billion or about 167 million more than the state originally forecast clymer said income taxes and corporate businesses taxes were showing particular strength although the figures are clearly good news for new jersey they also mean clymer and gov christine whitman will be on the defensive with the legislature over whitman 's plan to borrow 2.8 billion of pension bonds whitman wants to borrow the money to pay off the state 's 4.2 billion unfunded pension liability freeing up almost 600 million in budget savings with the maneuver but state lawmakers balking at the unprecedented size of the proposed borrowing have said part of the large surplus could be used to help balance the budget instead new jersey earlier this year selected merrill lynch co. to underwrite the deal if it wins legislative approval if issued in a single sale the taxable pension bonds would be the largest deal ever in the municipal bond market in a statement breaking down the state 's revenue collections so far this year clymer said april results were `` especially strong '' with 2 billion of revenues the income tax generated more than 4.1 billion for the period 100 million above forecasts and corporate business taxes totaled more than 1.1 billion 13 percent higher than revised expectations lottery collections were 522 million or 15.8 million below projections clymer said sales tax collections were roughly on target for the period -- steven dickson 212-859-1652

france will hold a tender on may 13 to sell 4,000 tonnes of soft wheat grain to nepal 4,000 tonnes of soft wheat grain to georgia and 730 tonnes of soft wheat flour to sri lanka as food aid national grain office onic said the wheat and the flour are for shipment in bags between may 30 and june 15 france will also hold a tender on may 13 for the supply of 5,110 tonnes of soft wheat flour under the u.n relief and works agency for palestinian refugees in the near east unrwa programme the flour will be shipped in bags to jordan lebanon syria and israel four lots are for shipment between may 30 and june 15 and one lot between august 23 and september 6 -- paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

the probability spain will be in european monetary and economic union emu from the start is now close to 100 percent according to a spanish banker `` the probability spain will be in the first wave of countries taking part in europe 's single currency is now close to 100 percent '' said pedro luis uriarte managing director of banco bilbao vizcaya bbv at a seminar `` it 's even higher than the probability of some core countries '' uriarte said he added that both the government and the bank of spain were `` working hard '' toward such an achievement -- madrid newsroom 341 585 8340

japan 's current account surplus the broadest measure of trade in goods and services dropped 19.6 percent in october from a year earlier to 367.4 billion yen the finance ministry announced on wednesday the average of economists forecasts had been a fall of about 9.6 percent in october from a year earlier to 413.1 billion yen the figures are released in yen at wednesday morning 's exchange rate of about 113 yen to the dollar october 's current account surplus was 3.25 billion the current account surplus has been falling on a year-on-year basis every month since december 1994 it totalled 457.1 billion yen 4.04 billion in october 1995 the year-on-year drop in september was 35.6 percent economists had expected the pace of the drop to slow in october due mainly to a slight fall in the trade surplus that month the overall trade surplus fell 12.9 percent in october from a year earlier to 470.86 billion yen 4.16 billion the 23rd consecutive month it has declined on a year-on-year basis

france 's economy needs shock treatment to boost sluggish growth cut unemployment and combat inequality socialist leader lionel jospin said on tuesday outlining his party 's economic programme for a march 1998 general election jospin said the socialists would provide the required jolt if they won `` we need to create a shock with a new policy of growth which is why i believe in the need for an original policy that strongly attacks unemployment and inequality and seizes france 's problems while building a europe that is both ambitious and attainable '' jospin told a news conference conservative prime minister alain juppe retorted in parliament that the socialist platform would `` lead france back into the spiral of decline '' france is suffering from record 12.7 percent unemployment and slow growth and the population is deeply sceptical of prospects for a lasting economic rebound the pressure to lower deficits to qualify for a single european currency is an extra constraint that would not relent under a different government to counter the problems jospin offered a plan to reduce the work week to 35 hours without cutting pay create 700,000 jobs -- mostly for the young -- and reform health insurance payments he said his policies offered a clear alternative to those of the centre-right government which he accused of focusing on electoral inducements at the expense of fundamental reform he contrasted his detailed policy statement with what he called the woolly `` communications events '' staged recently by president jacques chirac and juppe but his proposals while more reliant on state action were strikingly similar to some government policies in the last 18 months if they won the election which opinion polls suggest is unlikely the socialists hands would be tied by many of the same constraints hobbling juppe 's government though the ruling coalition still leads in most polls the socialists and their left-wing allies have edged to within striking distance a february 18 poll by bva for weekly paris match found that the left would win 31.5 percent of the vote an increase of two percentage points from a month earlier compared to 36.5 percent for the majority a decline of less than one point juppe 's government has removed some of the burden of funding the welfare state from payroll charges launched youth employment initiatives and enabled companies to reduce the work week all without making a dent in the jobless rate jospin charged that chirac was locked into backward-looking policies that kept the economy from achieving its growth potential which he put at three percent a year in 1996 the economy grew 1.3 percent and the government has said it expects growth of at least 2.3 percent this year `` a new situation demands new policies our problem is no longer inflation which has been beaten nor our trade balance which is in surplus our problem is mass unemployment '' he said while saying the primary solution to france 's jobs crisis lay in stronger private sector growth jospin pledged to create 350,000 public sector jobs in two years by creating a new long-term work contract he said this five-year contract would gradually replace existing shorter-term youth employment schemes it would be paid for by shifting money from existing initiatives as for the 350,000 private sector jobs he envisioned jospin said he would rely on a `` moral obligation '' among employers many of these jobs could be freed up by offering retirement to employees with 40 years service he said this measure would cost about eight billion francs a year for five years

china 's southern boomtown of shenzhen withdrew a net 7.0 billion yuan 840 million of cash from circulation in 1996 according to figures from the city branch of the people 's bank of china the central bank `` this is one indication that the financial sector of our city is in good condition '' the official xinhua news agency on thursday quoted a bank official as saying the banking system extended 101.1 billion yuan and recalled 83.6 billion yuan in loans last year he said outstanding deposits stood at 154.5 billion yuan at the end of the year up 28 percent while loans were 96.7 billion yuan at the year-end up 22 percent he said outstanding hard currency deposits at chinese banks rose by 106 million to 6.5 billion while outstanding foreign exchange loans were up 780 million to 6.4 billion he said the value insured in 1996 exceeded 500 billion yuan overseas financial institutions numbered 54 by year-end and of these 27 were operational their outstanding deposits stood at 750 million while loans totalled 3.7 billion he said 1 8.3 yuan

foreign secretary malcolm rifkind on thursday ruled out any change in the british government 's wait-and-see stance on whether to join the european union 's planned single currency he was speaking ahead of a discussion in cabinet of a briefing paper on monetary union that `` euro-sceptics '' in the ruling conservative party had hoped might prompt ministers to adopt an explicitly hostile line on the controversial question but rifkind told bbc radio `` the cabinet has already come to a conclusion i do n't see any evidence that there 's going to be a change '' he said the cabinet 's decision last april to keep its options open on the single currency -- taking advantage of the opt-out secured by prime minister john major when the project was agreed in 1991 -- was shared by the vast majority of conservative members of parliament this was because it was clearly in britain 's interest not to decide now whether to sign up for the single currency which is due to be launched on january 1 1999 `` does the national interest require a decision now the answer is `` no it does not british influence would be diminished and in any event decisions on this issue are going to be taken around about a year from now '' rifkind said he said the national interest was further protected because the conservatives -- like the main opposition labour party -- had promised to hold a referendum to endorse any future decision to scrap sterling in favour of the sinle currency `` so the british public would always have the last word against that background the national interest is very clear and quite unmistakable '' the foreign secretary said the paper due to be discussed at thursday 's weekly cabinet meeting has been drafted by finance minister kenneth clarke the government 's leading pro-european the report looks mainly at whether other european countries are `` fudging '' the criteria for entry into a single currency the paper was ordered before christmas when clarke came under pressure from ministers who wanted major behind in the polls and facing an election by may should take a more sceptical stance on the single currency rifkind confirmed he would be making a series of speeches to the people of europe in coming weeks over the heads of their politicians to set out britain 's vision of a flexible free-market europe `` the issue of the future of europe does n't just belong to the politicians it does n't just belong to diplomats '' he said `` we 're talking about jobs trade and the quality of life and therefore it 's right that the peoples of europe -- better educated than ever before -- should be fully part of that debate '' rifkind added

parliament approved congo 's 1997 budget with spending up 32.4 percent at 493.9 billion cfa francs 881 million on the expectation of higher revenues the official congo news agency said the government expected total revenues of 442.75 billion cfa and would make up the budget shortfall of 51 billion cfa through borrowing from official and multilateral creditors international monetary fund officials said the budget appeared to have passed the last hurdle the senate or upper house without amendments and its adoption is expected remove one problem in the central african country 's dealings with the imf and its other creditors the congo news agency quoted the government as saying increased spending was justified by a projected rise in revenues despite the persistence of deficits congo expects higher revenues both from a rise in oil exports and from an improved economy overall the agency said oil exports received a big boost with the inauguration last june of elf-aquitaine 's offshore nkossa production which is expected to push congo 's annual oil production to 13 million tonnes this year from nine million tonnes parliament last week adopted a law for the introduction of value added tax at the rate of 18 percent this year as part of measures to boost internal revenues the government said the leap in spending was necessitated by debt-servicing the cost of organising presidential elections next july and the government 's programme to fight poverty the approval by parliament of the 1997 budget was one of the conditions for continuing financial assistance laid down by the imf in its november 1996 review of congo 's efforts to get its economic house in order congo 's other creditors such as the so-called paris club of creditor nations have all made their continuing assistance dependent on the country sticking to the imf 's programme senators criticised the short notice at which the budget was brought before parliament they called on the government to take action to remedy the deterioration of infrastructure and services throughout the country after concern was expressed by local authorities the administration has been functioning since the beginning of the year on part of a provisional budget after a decree was passed to that effect at the beginning of january =565 cfa -- abidjan newsroom +225 21 90 90
